reviews.review:
Lovely relaxed and feel.. Fun bars, interesting boutiques (although I don't think the quality is that high and the prices were!).
It's just a great place to wander around and chill in.

Lively small grouping of streets, many quite tatty buildings. A few so fresco cafes around a square then pan out I to the surrounding do g streets. No many interesting shops, I'm sure THEY think they,'re interesting, but to a seasoned traveller it's nothing special.
Hi
Very cool area. Cool and trendy area in the heart of buenos aires. Lots of restaurants, bars and stores to choose from.
Hype and friendly. Feel like in hype and creative neighborhood of US city. Very bohemian-chic with quite 0-Traffic! Mix between tourists and residents.
Trendy, artsy, bohemian. Quiet, safe to walk cameras in hand, and very artistic, with lots of street art, trendy cafés, and elegant shops. Absolutely commendable!
Excellent for food and shopping. You can find lots of restaurants and walk around window shopping here. They have some of the best parilla and burger places.

NYC of Buenos Aires. My tour guide took me to Palermo Soho for the best pizza I ever had in my life. I was very surprised. This area is so hip and cool, It reminded me of NYC without the hustle or the crowds . The people are lively, active and stylish. You will find plenty of shops, restaurants, and a thriving nightlife. I want to rent one of the funky apartments here and stay for at least a month.

BS AS ALWAYS AT THE TOP. A place to enjoy the city`s energy, just relax and have a cup of coffee, you wont regret ! Palermo Soho is full of good, little places to dinner, enjoy life, enjoy being in Buenos Aires !

Excellent area for great food & shopping. It is a really safe area, with a great night life, awesome restaurants and cafes, and great shops, just a few stops away from the city centre of Buenos Aires. We stayed in the area and felt comfortable to walk around the area during the day & at night. There are a couple of markets in the area as well.
Mi lugar favorita. Mi lugar favorito en Buenos Aires best place to hang out with friends and have a beer, chill out and to have a great time
Stores and restaurants. Full of stores and restaurants, the best part is to have a drink at any bar near the little "plazas".
A great part of town. Some of the restaurants in this area are truly excellent and there is always something going on to watch. It has a real energy.

Great neighborhood and vibe . This is a great place to stay while in Buenos Aires. The vibe and people are awesome! We stayed at the Glu and the staff were wonderful. I recommend Palermo Solo to anyone visiting the city. Plenty of cabs to get you around to the major sites. There are some awesome eateries in the area as well. You will definitely enjoy.

A beautiful area of Buenos Aiires. We stayed here for two weeks and are longing to get back. So many different places of interest along Palermo Soho as well as stopping at many of the local restaurants or cafes.

Great Hip Neighborhood. We stayed in this area, so it was our home base. There are so many bars and restaurants around, we had no issues walking around at night, just use your head. You can walk to a few metro stops and Uber runs here.

Gorgeous neighbourhood. Spent a few nights in this area and really loved the vibes. There are plenty of bars, restaurants, cafes, shopping and a few parks to relax in the sun (if you're lucky to have a hot day). Fell in love with BA in this area of the city and can't wait to return.

Really Cool Residential N'hood. Even though many tourists are wandering around from their boutique hotels and Airbnbs, Palermo Soho absorbs everyone in stride. There is still a very local, laid-back feel in the neighborhood which sports many restaurants, cafes, bars and boutique shops. The area is connected to the rest of the city by subway through the Plaza Italia stop. Certainly all your needs for eating and drinking can be met here, but if you just want a bottle of wine, salami, cheese or water there are several little bodegas (convenience stores). Tip: the gelato at Tufic is Italian quality.

A nice area to stay and explore. There are many nice trendy shops to browse in and buy some interesting souvenirs. There are also many good restaurants and cafes. There is also a little flea market in Seranno Square. The area especially gets crowded at night with young people seeking dining and entertainment. The sidewalks are broken in many areas, so you must watch your step.
Nighlife. A great place for food and a drink. People are still eating and drinking at 1am and really are very friendly

Too trendy?. We went here for a meal and shopping but were slightly dissatisfied with both. The shops were a little too hip for us and generally out of our pride range, we ended up buying nothing at all though we did see nude stuff.

Great place to spend time and chill!. Somewhat reminds you of Manhattan Soho without the traffic jam! Great place for window shopping in a nice day. It's packed with trendy shops, boutiques, cafés, and restaurants away from traffic and crowd. Highly recommend it.

Not all the hype.. It's a far call to like this to anything in NYC. The pavenents are ruined. The shops are nice and the eateries are a little rough. It is typical of any attempt at Soho areas. Also be aware of the dog poo on the pavements.
For young desginers. What a great place to see fashion at its best in Buenos Aires. I had a hard time finding the best clothes for me because all sizes are super small!!!
Fun!. Fun, vibrant area of the city. Good shopping and people-watching by day; good food, drink and spirit by night.

Cool vibe at nights . I recommend this area for night. The Plaza Armenia offered play grounds for young children, our little one enjoyed them and worked up her appetite. The park is very dog friendly and she was very happy about that. Once we worked out an appetite we took a stroll around the Plaza and read and examines the many menus and different types of cuisine they had to offer. Variety is the key word here, you wills find the asado with a modern twist, Mexican, Chilean, pizza places and so on. The are plenty of bars around, but the vibe was mellow not loud. I suggest the area for a night walk.
great atmoshpere. Palermo soho is a great place to stay in Buenos Aires. Plenty of hotels, the neighborhood is full of nice restaurants, stores, life and clubs.

NYC in BA. We spent a morning walking around this quaint area of BA. Unless you are into shopping (we are not) or have time to relax in one of the many cafes (we did not) I wouldn't say this is a top attraction.
Buenos Aires' gem. Definitely a must. Wonderful atmosphere, especially in the evenings/ nights. Lots of trendy bars, restaurants and shops. Great place

Like other soho's but still worth it. A nice neighborhood to walk around in. Trendy shops. Café's. Nicer restaurants. Street vendors with local crafts and artist. If you have the to an arts district in other cities you will feel at home. A great way to walk off those empanadas.

Nice place to walk around . Many stores and young people all around.And many charming places to eat.I suggest Minga .. Minga is a very good place to eat during the week. Better for lunch because they offers a menu that includes a nice "chorizo" steak for a very good price.And the desert is included - I suggest a Crumble of apple very tastefull.The Minga is in front of the Armenia Square in the heart of Palermo Soho.

Was good, is bad. I come regularly to palermo soho since I usually stay 20mins from it, when in Buenos Aires. Soho once was "built" by artists and musicians and was quite an alternative lively place. Nowadays it just flooded with big brands like Diesel, Nike, Levis etc. But in Argentina these brands are much more expensive then in other countries. All local designers disappeared and the charming atmosphere of the neigbourhood vanished. Today the neighbourhood has a more exquisite touch and can't help but comes over very snobby.
Great place to hangout.. A place where there's always something going on. Plenty of parks to chill out in the day and loads of shops and bars, resteraunts to venture to at night!
Cool place!. This is a very colorful neighborhood with shops and tons of places to eat. Love to go there! There is a lot of boho and chic shops.
Used to be cool but nomas. Has become too touristy. But still fun to hang around.. Lots of bars, restaurants and independent boutiques
Aus. Great party area always something to do really enjoyed myself .. lots of thing to check out and saftey was never an issue

Nice place to eat out and shop. It's better place to eat and shop . It's regular place, your chance of getting cheated are less. Many good RESTURANTS ,boutique hotels. Good shops for leather if you are looking local brands . Be careful as now Chinese products hv infiltrated into local stuff,so be careful .

Nice boutique shopping district. Nice neighborhood to stay while visiting Buenos Aires. Tons of boutique shops with hardly any bargain, just window shop. Interesting cafe ms and bars dotted the neighborhood, pretty safe but do practice basic safety rule as applied locally.
Loved the ambiance!. This neighborhood is amazingly hipster, modern and cool. The colorful streets and young people around represents the creative area of buenos aires.

A trip to Beverly Hills in Buenos Aires. . One thing that is fun about buenos Aires is each neighborhood has a unique character. This one is fun! But a bit odd for a north American as it feels like home. The stores and cafes are just like Los Angeles.
Gorgeous. (May 2015) I intend to return to this area to do some more shopping, etc. The nightlife was plentiful here, from good restaurants to fun bars, and the street market was divine.

Trendy area. We spent the day wandering around here and enjoyed the area- quite trendy and safe area. However, I have to confess, I prefer Las Cañitas where we are staying for choice of restaurants and neighborhood.

Apartment. We're staying in this area an it's our first visit. There is so much going on here and the restaurant and bar scene is very cool. It's a vibrant area and way different to the touristy parts of BA and way better
You must be there. If you are traveling to Buenos Aires you must stay at Palermo Soho. There is a variety of good restaurants, Bars and entertainment
Safe and trendy. Trendy and artsy neighborhood. Great restaurants, boutique shops, fairs/festivals on weekends in two parks. Very safe to walk around alone and even at night.

Happening art and design scene. An ordinary urban neighborhood has been transformed into an incredibly hip art and design scene. Don't miss it. Also, take the Graffitimundo tour--it was well worth the time and money and gave a much better understanding of the street art all around you in Palermo Soho.

A charming district to stay, eat, shop, or just hang around. This charming district of Bs.As. has some distinguishing features that resemble the Manhattan Soho. It is full of little shops, cafés, small restaurants, as well as cozy small hotels, and squares where arts and crafts markets offer different types of goods for sale. It is a must in a sightseeing tour!

Favorite part of the City. We have walked all over Buenos Aires and found our selves returning to Palermo. The place is wonderful at night and during the day. Lots of great restaurants and cafes and lots of shopping. If I had to move to his city I would try to live close to this area.

Fashion and cool in an old zone.. Palermo the first neighborhood was a quiet area with cheap houses and lots of garages. Like is any world big city one store starts up a new trend and the cheap houses nowadays are beautiful boutiques, fancy restaurants, cool bars, disco, small coffee shop ideal as meeting point. Endless stores -special for women- and "beauty people" walking along the old street. If you want to buy up-today dress or shoes go to Palermo Soho. If you want to have a cozy dinner go to Palermo Soho. If you want to have fun go the a new district with a Buenos Aires flavor.

Beautiful place to walk around!. Spent a few hours in the afternoon walking around Palermo and loved it.An ideal place to take a stroll while checking out the many stores, little cafes and restaurants from places around the world.Plenty of bars and places to grab a bite, even ran into a stand up place one night.Love Palermo, eclectic and inviting!
Go!. Lots of little shops and great restaurants, bars and cafes! Loved it!Look out for some of the arty graffiti! Never felt unsafe here.

Great Neighborhood to stay in and explore from. This is a great area for walking, dining and shopping. We rented a house in this area for a week, and while we enjoyed exploring Recoleta, San Telmo, La Boca and downtown, we loved this area best. It's walking distance to La Cabrera, Proper, Cosi Mi Piace (fabulous pizza), Cocu, Ninina, Pain et Vin (an adorable wine bar) and plenty of great shopping. We liked the Argentine rugs at Elementosargentinos.
Shopping Premo. Great spot to people watch and go for a wander. I preferred the discount centre on Paraguay same shops just discounted. But worth lunch and wander

This is the best neighbourhood for wandering around!!!. We walked many neighbourhoods in our week in BA. We found that Palermo Soho was the absolute best for walking around. There are tons of local fashion stores, restaurants, coffee shops, ice cream places etc. Each street has something interesting. Note that you should check restaurant recommendations ahead of time though as some of the more well travelled streets have some pretty poor food. We had our best food experience in Soho and our worst so try to have a list of potentials before you hit the neighbourhood.

Nobody knew the area. I wish I could say more good things about the area but to get there was like a puzzle. Nobody was sure how to get there. Welch got multiple direction and none of them coincided.After gathering information, we finally found the area. I was exhausted Ana at the end I wanted to go home because reality didn't quite meet the expectation.

Must Visit. Palermo Soho is a hip, vibrant, yet not maddening, part of Buenos Aires. There are just tons of boutiques, restaurants and cafes. While it is very commercial it is charming as this part of Palermo does not have any large or tall buildings.
intrresting and very nice to explore. this is an interesting Neighborhood , sit, walk around and enjoy the special atmosphere, good shops and restaurants
Loved staying here. Trend on point . This barrio has it all. Best restaurants , quality shopping , cool street art , great bars and pubs and a plethora of art and cool people watching
Amazing. Great neighborrhood where you can see Bohemian Buenos Aires at its best, full of artists and nice shops around.

Trendy area with lots of shopping options. Nice trendy area with lots of shopping options. Safe neighborhood to walk around in and just window shop. This is a tourist area so the prices are higher here.

A lovely area to base yourself in Buenos Aires. The area is safe, vibrant and full of great restaurants so you never have to go far to get a wonderful meal. It's about a 20 minute walk to either subway line to take you to interesting sights and other areas of Buenos Aires. Be careful of the sidewalks here and all over the city - they are uneven, missing chunks, and there are often holes that can break your ankle. Also watch for dog doo-doo on the sidewalks.

Lovely & lively !!. Its trendy , up market & hence a bit expensive. Huge choice for shopping of your liking- variety , quality & style. Teeming with people, shoppers , its fun to be there even if you dont pick any thing.
A must to enjoy & soak in Flavour - Argentina !

nice place to stroll. Went for a walk out here. Lots to look at but it felt a bit fake. The shops were mainly set up for tourists and the outlet mall was very highly priced. A beautiful square though with restaurants scattered around it and we had the most amazing meal. If you have time its good for a stroll but I wouldn't stress about fitting it into a busy timetable

Cool and funky. Palermo Soho is a shopping place with plenty of shops offering different styles and varieties. I enjoy walking around this place. Do visit this place if you ever travel to Buenos Aires for the first time

Favorite place in all of BA. We travel to BA a lot and never pass up the visit to Palermo. Soho is not really accepted by Portenos, it's all Palermo and then people started calling neighborhoods next to Palermo, palermo this Palermo that, to make Palermo even bigger. So when you tell the taxi one or the other, he will know but will snicker. Plaza Serrano is in this area of Soho and is a must do for first time and frequent visitors of BA. Great shops, Great street vendors and artists and super restaurants and cafes, you can easily spend a couple of days here. In fact, it's really great if you can stay in the area and do everything by foot, with the caveat that Palermo is happening and some hotels might be less soundproofed than others.
Something for everyone . This area is great. Leisurely stroll great coffee and cafes. Niece shops. Felt safe the whole time. People were friendly.
Shopping. Very nice place to go on sunday and have a brunch! There are many stores to buy clothes! be ready to walk !
Better at Night . Just my opinion more entertainment at night. Sort of boring in the morning, except for a couple of good coffee stops and some shopping. But at night lots of activities

I want to live here!. Cool cafes, bars and restaurants everywhere. Hipster kind of vibe but not in your face. Very fashionable place to be and great for people watching. Nice To just wander the streets and soak up the atmosphere, cool markets at the weekends. It's the place to be and be seen!

Excellent Place to spend 5 hours. . Lovely Place. It has a sign of its own. Must do in Buenos Aires. We enjoyed. Lovely shops. Great café. Super Food. Nice time to spend. See nice things, appreciate the off tangent things... Highly recommended. Bhagwan.

Amazing food and drinks in this district. Free wifi can I state which helped us dramatically looking for bars,Clubs and restaurants. Amazing food in Rave and drinks in Vivivan. Then a night in Rose bar which wasn't what we expected but soho is so beautiful feels like east village NYC
Shopping and restaurants. Tree-lined streets, shopping district, outlets, restaurants, bars, friendly people treat you at any of these places.

For the youth. It was a degraded neighborhood (scenery of many of Borges' stories), that in the last years was converted in a shopping and food center.- Lots of cafés and restaurants along with clothes stores.- Tripadvisor tells you that Honduras street is the main center of activity but is wrong.- The activity is centered in El Salvador and Costa Rica streets between Malabia and Fray Justo Santa María de Oro streets, in total about 10 whole blocks.-

Nice place for people watch. Great place for people watch, with a good mix of locals and tourists. F&B prices are generally on the high side - with some interesting shops and small flea markets. However, just a note that English is still not well understood and spoken by the service staff even in this touristy part of BA - was rudely ignored at one of the F&B outlets for not understanding what I wanted - even though was a simple order of coffee and pastries.
delightful location in Buenos Aires. lots to see and do in the area, smazing shopping, and restaurants aplenty. highly recommend this location to travellers
Wonderful area to walk around in. You can spend a day wandering around the little streets of Palermo Soho. Lots of interesting shops and cafés. Very boheme.

Seems Like A Great Area!!. The reason I was in this area was to attend a wine tasting. To get to this area from Florida Street where I was staying, I took a cab, which are cheap and readily available. The cab fare with tip was 150 Pesos, which made it 22 US dollars. For a 25 minute cab drive I did not feel this was bad. Once I got to this area, and upon completing my wine tasting, I took time to walk the neighborhood for awhile. It is not as commercial driven as Florida Street. I felt very safe, merchants and business both seemed appreciative of my being in this area. Sometimes, and some places, one can feel 'not so welcomed'. But that certainly was not the case here. I wish I would have been able to spend more time there in the daylight areas. It really seems like a great place.
Nice Walk. This area looks so much like Soho downtown New York, lots of shopping and very nice restaurants and bars.

Beatiful, picturesque and vibrant neighbourhood. Palermo Soho is one of the best places to go out for coffee, lunch, shopping, dinner or drinks in Buenos Aires. With plenty of nice restaurants, lively bars and quirky shops, it attracts a young crowd and is a good place to mix with locals while enjoying the nightlife of Buenos Aires.
LearningnSpanish. Vibrant neighborhood with tons of restaurants, bars, stores and wine shops. Very casual and cool. Close to the big park with bike lanes throughout the area.
Most interesting neighbourhood. Go there Enjoy the atmosphereThe foodThe shoppingThe walkingThe colorsThe Palermo Felt very at ease just getting a little lost. Very quite in the mornings.

Great brunch. We are from New York, so with a name like Palermo Soho, we were curious to visit. The area was okay, nothing like the Soho we know, but it did serve it's purpose as an afternoon Sunday destination. lots of shops, a street fair and many fine restaurants and quaint bars line it's streets. Nice place to visit, we had a great lunch at La Cabrera, which we highly recommend.

A FABULOUS place to stay and/or visit!. I would pick this area to stay in if you're any age from teens to old age! Our great hotel was on Gurruchaga near Costa Rica and it was just at the beginning of where there were many wonderful shops and lots of restaurants. People are out into the late night, but it's pretty quiet. It has good subway and bus access with the 39 public bus and the green line subway on Santa Fe (Plaza Italia stop). It's near the zoo and parks and about a 90 minute leisurely walk to Plaza de Mayo.
Nice place . Four shopping and for restaurants, offers a lot. Designers boutiques with clothes made in Argentina mostly. I would definitely come back again.

a great area to browse, eat, and drink. This is a great area to wander in and out of the Streets from Honduras to Costa Rica to Guatemala. Overflowing with pavement eateries and fine dining rooms plus bars, bars, and more bars. Throw in several street markets and you are set.

Great neighborhood night and day. Most trendy area in the city both during the day and at night. A ton of shopping and design stores, plus a bunch of funky multi spaces hosting local designers. Tons of cafes and restaurants. Great bars at night!
Best place to stay. Excellent shopping and restaurants. There was also a market and the nightlife was hopping. I would stay in that area again

Great neighborhood. We headed to Plaza Serrano as suggested by the Exec Lounge staff - lots of restaurant, bars, shops and really nice and fun place to hang with friends and coworkers. There are choices for everyone. It is also nice to walk around the Palermo neighborhoods
Clothes Shopping Bars and restaurants. Lots of bars and restaurants around this area and very good for clothes shopping. Most definitely worth a visit

Young and trendy Buenos Aires area. I was there last weekend after a long time. Loved seeing how many new coffee shops and bars there are apart from the trendy clothes shops. Great for chilling out with friends.
The best place to stay. This low-rise area has developed rapidly over the last decade or so. it's trendy, lively, green, informal and not too far from the centre.

Here is where the action is. We stayed in this part of town, though we are not exactly young, but found the energy and the young people watching very lively. Street cafes, lots of restaurants and many many shops, all catering to the youthful fashions of BA, like the 6 inch platform shoes! Urban are, restored old buildings, outdoor cafes and street musicians- this is the area for strolling into the wee hours.

Coolest part of BA . Amazing bars, restaurants and vibe. Place to see and be seen. Big hangout for BA locals. Amazing local vibe, so not your typical tourist trap area. Prices are fair and service in the establishments in the area is great. A must see.

Go Boho. Palermo Soho is a bastion of Boho chic. It's fun to just wander through the streets, whether you are shopping or not. While I shopped, my husband sat on a bench and sketched a street scene.There are numerous little coffee shops and lots of fun restaurants. Much of the graffiti is like fine art!If I could only visit one neighborhood in Buenos Aires, it would be Palermo Soho.
Good area to stay for restaurants and relatively secure.. Trendy area with good choice of restaurants,bars and shops. Try also Baez in Palermo, Las Cañitas- I find this even better.

No not London New York or Surrey Hills or Newtown. Go if you have time and enjoy strolling through suburbs but it's quite scattered. I did it by chance and had enjoyed it but didn't return at night to see whether life took off then.

Best Barrio. So nice neighbourhood to walk in, with cobblestone streets, on eor two floor houses, a lot of cafés and restaurants and great shops filled with excentric stuff. My favorite neigbourhood i BA.
very cool and quirky!. great restaurants and bars and lots of small boutique shops! Would definitely recommend a visit or even staying in this area.

Overrated area. Not a fan. a few blocks of what is supposed to look like downtown New York. It does not. There are a handful of cute stores but the area is dicey and I did not feel safe in the afternoon.

great place for a walk and amazing restaurants. you can experience what Buenos Aires night life is all about, go there around 8:30 pm for dinner and stay late enjoying all that that area has to offer.

Food, Art, Shopping and Parks. Palermo is known for its parks and Palermo Soho does not disappoint. There is so much to see/do here. The cobblestone streets are home to many turn of the 20th century mansions and apartment buildings. Almost every corner has charming cafes. Home to many artists, there are numerous art galleries open to the public. There are many trendy shops selling clothes, accessories and jewelry. There is a youthful vibe here with a big nightlife scene - most restaurants don't open for supper until 8:30pm.

Perfect Place to Stay!. We booked a house and stayed in Palermo Soho for a week. Loved the shops, galleries, restaurants, cafes and generally great vibe in the neighborhood. The shopkeepers and waiters/servers couldn't have been any more hospitable during our stay. I would stay in Palermo Soho again when coming to BA.

La boheme. Soho in London,in New York or in BA;all seem to cater to the same crowd.Nice shops in old buildings,ecclectics restaurants,people watching and window shopping.Colorful art everywhere.Typical soho groove again if you like that kind of thing!
A lovely neighbor in BA. Just walking about you get a full range of insite into what the Argentine's flavor for shopping and restaurants. Lots of local sites and people.

Very good neighborhood. Just go there and walk along the street see the old type houses abd graffitis. If it is evening or near to sunset try having some drinks. It is a cozy, trendy neighbodhood. Loved here.
Fuss about nothing. It's just a very artificially created residential area to walk around. Worth seeing just for a walk. The restaurants and craft stalls are a bit of a an international cliche.
The happy part of the city. Great atmosphere, small restaurants and shopping. This is the trendy part of the city, where you find backpackers and hipsters.

odd place. Visited here on our city tour, which allowed us 30 minutes to explore. Old buildings painted bright colors and lots of little shops and cafes. Also tango dancers hoping you will want a l ittle dance for a tip.
Best part of Buenos Aires!. All the backpackers and travelers are there, and locals hang out there too....best restaurants and bars. There is good shopping also.
Where my friend Lucas lives. This palermo is a very nice neighborhood in Buenos Aires. A very nice part of the city to hang out with friends. Had a great time here.

Loved the neighbourhood feel. Would love to stay near here next time I´m in Buenos Aires. It has a lively vibe, lots of interesting shops and galleries. Huge variety of eats and all a bit cheaper than elsewhere in the City

Coolest Neighborhood. It is certainly the coolest neighborhood in Buenos Aires.
Small and trendy bars, famous resturants, vintage shops, setting out a cool vibe.

The Area. I stayed in Palmera in a lovely boutique hotel. The area is quite large, so be prepared to walk, taxi or use subway. All which is absolutely fine and enables you to get a feel of local area.

Stayed here when in BA - great choice.. In the suburbs, also the height of activity. Buy a bus pass and BA is open to everything - we used 3 routes and saw a lot, also great value. We now can take any taxi driver for a ride and know when they are trying to do!

Fab. Palermo Soho is a great area to stay in Buenos Aires. I have just came back from 4 nights there. The area is very safe day and night. There is lots of great restaurants and bars around. Good for young and older travelers. Its about a 20 minute walk to the nearest subti station but we eventually cottoned on to getting a taxi to the subway around £3 well worth it in the heat. There was beautiful boutique type shops if a little expensive, but unusual clothes etc. I would stay there again if I am lucky enough to go back. We stayed in the Mine hotel fabulous, highly recommend.

See Mr Katz.....he,s the cats whiskers.. A small area but with several artisan shops including working jewellers, one of whom was Isaac Katz, Pasaje Santa Rosa, he makes rings, pendants and all sorts of things with lovely stones of all covers..worked into silver and very well priced. I got through to him in Yiddish !

Nice district around Scalabrini Ortiz street. Nice design shops with unique clothes, accessories, etc. Will recommend the place for a good rest among weekend, including shopping (if you are interested in not mass market), restaurants, beer pub. Quite and lovely. Good place for youth.

Walk, talk & eat. Nice neighborhood, people from all over (turists and locals), excellent food, nice small shops, artists on the street selling their art... You can walk around the blocks, and you may find different interesting nice shops, e g bookstores, music stores, clothing stores, design shops... Some of them are a bit expensive but overall very interesting stuff and ok w the budget.

Relaxed cobble streets with good bars and shops. For a relaxed urban feel, spend some time strolling through the leafy and cobbled streets, which really come alive in the evening with bars and restaurants.

Fabulous urban location. Six of us stayed in a 3 bedroom 3 bath lux penthouse complete with roof terrace on Guatemala Street in Soho. Location was 4 blocks off the main center of Buenos Aires, yet the feeling and ambience was urban and cozy (yes that is possible). Shops and markets were within minutes of our front door. Soho was very clean with a nice vibe we all felt.

Walking by - seeing and be seen. What else to fill a sunny afternoon. Just wander and windowshop.Many international and Argentinian brands and local flavour in the streets. People: couples, friends, after office, families and babies. Everyone is there!

Search and ye shall find. At first you walk around this area thinking "What is the big deal" and then as you wander you suddenly find a nest of great shops or great bars, a little square full of cafes, a trendy restaurant or two. All of a sudden you start to find more and more and you suddenly realise why this area is the up and coming area of BA. This is somewhere you want to stroll around on a Friday afternoon about 5pm, EVERYWHERE just comes alive. Lots of unique shops, bars and restaurants. Go and see for yourself but be prepared to hunt for the areas, it isn't just offered to you on a plate.
Great area. This is a fantastic area of Buenos Aires. Good hotels lots of cafes bars and safe to walkvabout in daytime as well as night

Soho is coming to Buenos Aires. Just like in New York City SOHO is lively, surprising, colorful, entertaining and very interesting. Although the area is limited in size you can spend there half a day easily.
Expensive, trendy place. Its full of little colorful boutiques, good to look, expensive to buy. We found a good restaurant outside, but it was full of doves landing on the tables

Very interesting area. This part of town has been transformed to a lively cafe, bar, shopping and restaurant area. It is safe to walk around this area at any time and there are plenty of good restaurants for lunch or dinner. As many places are painted very colorful it is a great place to take some nice pictures.

wear walking shoes. and be prepared for cobblestone streets. no, i wouldn't compare it to nyc soho which some people have suggested. lots of shopping and lots of cafes but nothing out of the ordinary. there are virtually no trees so make sure you have a hat and sunscreen. no big deal unless you want to spend your money.

Don't miss it!. This is an awesome neighborhood to stay in if you are visiting Buenos Aires - tons of great places to eat, drink, sit, shop, walk around. Lots of energy all week and all hours. It is also close to the subway and Plaza Italia. Can't think of a better place to stay in the city on vacation.

Night market quite the buzz. Unique street markets set up in the evening, filled with a wide variety of local vendors.It is fun to explore, hit the casual bars and restaurants.Nice place to go before dinner, or on the weekends.Bring CASH only!
Great Place to Buy!. Full of restaurants, designer stores, and lots of flohmarkets. If you want to buy pretty stuff this is the place.
Chi chi upscale neighborhood. Lots of shops and restaurants in a very upscale neighborhood. Very active in the evening . Fun to walk around ,mingle and eat.

I love this area. This area is full of bars and restaurants and most importantly I think this area is safe. During the weekend there are street markets around the park area which i love most! I'm not a party animal so I'm not eager to have the nightlife but I could have other choices for my dinner. it's not close to the metro but if i visit BsAs again i will definitely choose to live in this area again
Nice for a stroll. A relaxed neighborhood with all the modern stores you want. This is not your typical local Buenos Aires neighborhood, and filled with all the big fashion brands.

Love it!. Palermo Soho is a modern, beautiful area in Buenos Aires, full of great restaurants, bars, fancy clothing and decór stores, good hotels and lots of marvelous green areas to visit. Perfect for day and night!

Such a cool place!. We loved it around here. We're from Sydney, and found it to be like Darlinghurst/Surry Hills with lots of little bars and cafes mixed with boutique shops in nice streets. We spent two whole days just walking around, browsing, eating, drinking... great place. If I moved to BA, I would live in Palermo Soho!
Great Food, Shopping, and Nightlife. We went once during the day and once at night. The neighborhood turns into a buzzing nightlife seen.

Expensive hipsterhood. It is a nice area to go for lunch and drinks and walk around the shops although in summer during the day it gets too hot in the streets. The shops are very expensive though esp international brands they cost at least 3 times more than in Europe...
Alternative. Must see when in BA. Lots of small shops, cafes and restaurants. Relaxed atmosphere all over. Perfect neighborhood to stroll around.

a Must in Buenos Aires. Full of eateries, garment shops and bars, this is a preferred area for tourists and locals. there are also many boutique hotels and hostels nearby. The subway and Santa Fe avenue is 5 blocks away. It's a bustling district at night. Great choice for everyone!

Lived up to the reviews. What an amazing area of Buenos Aires. Obviously this is an area where people with a healthy bank account reside. Apartments are one million US dollars and up. Beautiful area to stroll around. Many nice restaurants and coffee shops.

Fun to visit, interesting mix of old and new. I stayed in Palermo to experience a little of its street life. In the day I took lots of photos and enjoyed a couple of good meals in the evenings. There is an outlet mall near Av Juan B. Justo (boring). But it is worth visiting the area for the anti-Shell oil mural nearby.

One of the most vibrant areas in Buenos Aires. We stayed for five days here. while it is difficult to get to other areas, it is a great destination with great night life, fun boutiques and many good restaurants in several price points. Worth your time for an evening for sure. Start at Plaza Serrano and end in plaza serrano, but walk the the streets and enjoy the vibancy. If you can stay here it is much more alive at night than other places. so day trip from here to Recoleta, Santelmo etc and then return for a late dinner.

The best neighborhood for just hanging out. If you're in the city for any amount of time and want to get a sense for modern Argentine culture, grab a meal and walk around the Palermo soho district. The shopping is eclectic and fun, the food is diverse and so are the people. We ate at the classic parilla, La Cabrera. Highly recommend having a late lunch there and walking it off for the rest of the afternoon.

Loved staying in this neighborhood. We rented a place for nine days via Airbnb and could not have been more pleased with location. Loads of bars, cafes and retail, all with an artsy, bohemian vibe to it.
Nice BUT THE SHOP.... This is a very nice and comfortable area full of shops and bars and restaurants bit it is much nicer during the night. Shops are good but mostly the same...

Best part of BA!. Cool, laid-back, hip and happening. Palermo Soho is all that. A good place for walking around and marveling the architecture as well as sitting down in one of the innumerable cafes, bars or restaurants and just chilling out with a beer.

Shopping, Shopping, Shopping. Palermo is a great place to look for the unique gifts and fashion items that make a memorable holiday. The district is full of the smaller boutiques with unusual. It is a strolling and visual feast. Make sure you leave time to dine early and enjoy the sidewalk culture. Start at Plaza Serrano and then branch out along the three lines streets.

A Bohemian Hood.... A nice bohemian neighborhood with lots to offer from nice restaurants and bars to nice fair and shops. Its usually a common place for small boutique hotels and a kind of pricey area to book an airbnb but its a popular choice for most of tourist because of the nice atmosphere and how easy is to move around. In my opinion, the area keeps a bohemian attitude (not a fan) but at the same time its a very populated area to move around with lots of traffic and noise. Its a nice place to visit and, from the city hoods, this might be one of the most colorful (like La Boca). For a stroll and to find a nice restaurant, this area might be a good place to start searching around, for sure...

Great neighbourhood. We stayed three nights in Palermo Soho, and as the names indicates it does remind one of Soho in New York City, or Shoreditch in London. Lots of cafes/bistros, boutique shops, very casual, easy going vibe, but not grubby or seedy. Also close to the Plaza Italia and the parks. If I moved to BA this is where I'd live.

palermo. nice place to stay if in BA . not too expensive, lots of cafes and shops, not far from the park spaces and public transport. only problem i have is crossing streets, drivers do not like to give way.
Palermo Soho. very nice experience, lots of stores, lots fashion, new designers, the are looks very very nice, lots of restaurants

Very trendy but relaxed neighborhood. This neighborhood is better everyday that you come by. Full of trendy shops (nice, very well decorated but expensive) and great restaurants, this area is covered by trees and green areas that makes the place very relaxing. We stayed there and was the best one!

New neighborhoods. This area is one of the most fashion places in Buenos Aires.
Millions of restaurants and bars,one better than the other,all the new clothes designers.Shoes,antiques and modern furniture.Nice place to go at night to eat and Saturday and Sunday to see the designers and be seated in many coffee store around.
Very interesting area.

a hipster's holiday. Sally sez: this is a great walking/shopping place for hipsters. Over a certain age, you will either not find your style or your size. Even so, it is lots of fun, with excellent restaurants if you get tired

Very nice place to hang. Lots of restaurants, Cafes, bars.
There are some nice galleries and it is close to public transportation.
Highly recommended.
The Greenwich Village of BsAs. Love the entire Palermo areas. Great restaurants, bars, shops, tiny parks, great people watching, boutique hotels.

Great Food and Shops. The Soho and Hollywood areas of the Palermo district most resemble US neighborhoods full of boutique shops, bars and restaurants. The prices are much higher here than in Centro and Puerto Madero districts. Also most places we went into didn't accept US dollars (and there weren't any banks or exchanges to speak of.) the cafe we ate at was reasonable but the quality of beef etc wasn't on par with the other areas mentioned before.

One of my favorite neighborhoods in Buenos Aires. I love this place, it's full of little cafes, restaurants, quirky stores, flea markets, street artists, ice cream.....Some shop owners have covered the trees in front of the stores in colorful fabrics giving the streets almost a fairy tale feel to it.For me it's the perfect way to spend the afternoon and work your way into night life.

Trendy And Interesting. Full of cafes and restaurants and small shops and many people on a Sunday this is a trendy place mainly for younger people. The nearby area of Palermo was more sedate and classy

Best night in Palermo. if you want to go this place l will prefer Friday night or Saturday night after 11 pm there are more people in Palermo so there are many bars,cafes,rest,some shops there and very easy walking around and all bars and restraints it's very close each other so you can walking one to other one
A fun district in B.A.. It is great to see this area develop and become the "in" place for the new shops and restaurants. A great area to visit.

Quaint area. This is a pretty area full of sidewalk cafes and boutiques (not tacky tourist souvenirs, mostly upscale designers and housewares). If you're on a whirlwind tour of BsAs, you may not want to take the time here as there isn't a lot of "sightseeing," but fit it in if you can!

Go when the weather is sunny. We spent three nights here when it rained most of the time and returned two weeks later when the weather was hot and sunny - what a difference!
The area is packed with individual shops, bars and restaurants and you can wander around for hours in a happy frame of mind

Very Bohemian. Very cute little bohemian town. Great restaurants and the best part is that they are all within walking distance. Only bad part is that Argentians party late...and so we didn't really get to experience the dancing life of this town- but the food and drinks were great.
Trendy area!. I stayed in this area for a few days which was a great experience. Plenty of cafes, bars, restaurants and boutique stores to spend hours in. Happy exploring.
Fun part of town. . This was a neighborhood that remembered Soho in NY. Really cute coffee places and great for lunch. Also one can have fun in the shops if in t me mood for it;)

Probably the best neighborhood in BA. The neighborhood is vibrant and friendly. There are numerous boutiques, all of them unique, for those who try to get away from the typical mall-like shops. Plenty of bars, cafes and restaurants, which I might say without mistaking, can satisfy every taste. All in all, an energetic area, the perfect place to have a good time, meet people, and in my opinion experience BA life.

Just like New Yorks Soho, but in Buenos Aires. The area was a cute little area to walk around, its not really my scene. The shops are more alternative which is not really me. Its definitely an area to walk around in but i wouldnt spend more than an hour or two there.

A great must see area away ffrom the madness of BA. Would 100% include this as any part of a visit to BA. Very hip, trendy and fun. Would not miss. Well worth an afternoon to explore. Its actually a big area, WE walked between the two small parks in the area, but part of hte fun is gong up and down various streets to see what you see.

Nice area. We just stayed in Soho and it was perfect, walking distance to cafes, pubs and underground bars!! Cute area and we felt pretty safe. A lot of police presence around. Would stay in this area again
Hip area with very chic restaurants. Very quiet and nice area with a lot of nice and chic restaurants. Visited there and had Italian food there, awesome!

Lovely area to wander in, great neighbourhood to stay in. Full of great cafes, bars and restaurants, individual shops of all kinds, street art, lovely old buildings and very safe. You could wander here for days and still find something new round every corner. Great area to stay in. Really good craft markets at weekends in Plaza Serrano and Plaza Vieja. Easy to reach on the Subte. Not just touristy - a real locals hang out too. Still slightly boho.

The best neighbourhood in Buenos Aires!. Do not think twice when booking your hotel/airbnb in BA. Without a doubt Palermo is the best place to stay. With little trendy shops, quirky coffee shops and delicious restaurants you will be in the heart of the city. It's the best place for strolls. Absolutely loved it!
Cool Neighbourhood. There's always something to do here, tons of restaurants, bars, shopping. Definitely recommend the area!!
Lovely. Lovely area to go for a wonder in Buenos aires. Nice vibe and lots of restaurants. Worth a visit....

Go there, and get lost!. We liked this neighborhood more than Palermo Hollywood. Every street has its own beauty, and this area is amazing on Saturdays. There are tons of cafes and restaurants, and you can find something according to your taste.

Ordinary in the day - Interesting at night. It's 6pm on October 16th and I have just come back from Palermo Soho. In the day this is just another ordinary semi-elegant and semi-bohemian area of Buenos Aires, with its fashion stores on one hand and its pubs and restaurants getting ready for the week end nights on the other. At night the atmosphere changes, and here's where one half of Buenos Aires club-goers meet at night (the other half meets in Recoleta). Here you'll find an enless series of differently decorated bars, pubs, cafes and restaurants offering all possible drinks and foods - booth national and foreign. Food prices are reasonable compared to Western cities, but once you order any alcoholic drink which is not beer prices go uo just like in London, Paris or Rome.
great hipster-y vibe. Yummy coffee, restaurants, quirky stores, trees, paved streets. Fun. Liked reading the English-language newspaper at Full City Coffeehouse

Not as the tourist guides say. We stayed at a hotel in Palermo Soho. The first thing we did was to stroll around the place. There were a few design shops but I didn´t see anything worthit...Next time we`ll stay at Recoleta!

Shoppers delight for finding Argentinian disigners, very fashionable. This is a swanky neighborhood full of boutiques and nice restaurants and bars. There are many very fashionable Argentinian designers that have their shops here. My wife and daughters were in shopping heaven. The merchandise is rarely available outside of South America and excited all my girls immensely. They bought a lot of stuff and got many compliments on the pieces. If you (are a woman) and don't want to worry about showing up at an event with the same dress on as any other woman, buy one here and your odds are reduces significantly. The dining options are global. We wandered her numerous times for lunch and dinner.

A Nice Area to Visit and Shop. Stayed at a hotel in Palermo Soho. Enjoyed walking around. Visiting the shops and enjoyed the restaurants and bars. It is an older area, but alive with the young and the young at heart. If in Buenos Aires a nice area to spend time in.

If you are young and trendy, do not miss!!. First, it is not "rua" but "calle Honduras" (Spanish, not Portuguese!)Best time to go is after 11 PM and in a warm night. Stroll and join all the young hip people of Buenos Aires. For couples is a must! It is the place for anyone who is into design (clothing, furniture, restaurants, etc) You must walk at least 10 blocks to see the whole picture. Unique in Latin America.
Great location. There wonderful restaurants and cafes nearby as well as the botanic garden, the rose garden, and museums and historical sites nearby. The area felt very safe for walking everywhere.
Very nice area to walk and a for a good dinner. There are a ton of restaurants and bars to enjoy the fantastic international cuisine and the local asado.

Wonderful Part of the city. A bustling and vibrant section of BA. Plenty of restaurants, pubs and clubs to visit. A word of warning..... the fun doesn't start until well after 12 midnight so pace yourself !!

Nice saturday stroll.... Nice place to walk about, enjoying some window shopping or some actual shopping! Good restaurants. Saturday hás a little market. Touristic but entertaing, not as overwhelming as San Telmo market.
Feels like SOHO New York. Wonderful area to just walk around and enjoy. There are restaurants, people watching, shopping, and sites to see on every block.
I love Soho. My favorite Sunday is spent having lunch in Soho then shopping. I love discovering new shops and stopping for coffee or food at one of the many excellent cafes. I really love Soho.

Crowded with beautiful young people.. Palermo Soho is the newest attraction in Buenos Aires but keeps the flavor of ancient times. A few decades ago in this area were a lot of workshops. The good taste of the Argentinians converted these workshops into restaurants, caffes, pubs, etc. Young people everywhere in a peaceful and enjoyable place.

Feeling Fancy. We stayed in nice posh suburb for 3 nights on our first arrival in Buenos Aries, Argentina. Many streets to walk around with fancy, restaurants, pubs and Cafes. Some restaurants were a bit expensive , however the the food was delicious and you decent size meals. so it's worth it.
Porteño neighbourhood. Nice atmosphere of this typical Porteño neighbourhood of inner Buenos Aires, trendy, with nice places to eat & shop

Amazing. Is great to go at after office or dinner, amazing areas, with good restaurants and pubs, you ll enjoy the buildings,shops, restos and people. GOOD. can arrive by metro. At friday night is nice place

Absolutely amazing area.. . I went for business trip in April and wether was great.. I was free sometimes and walking in the area which was surrounded by millions nice restaurants and coffee which make you confuse to where to go because you want to try all!! The night life never going to end as people just start to go out around midnight..

Different look to Buenos Aires. Buenos Aires’ largest barrio, Palermo, (by size) beckons expats, vacationers and an ever-growing number of porteños like moths to a flame. Regardless of where you choose to live/stay, it’s pretty much a foregone conclusion that most of the people you know and meet in the city will live in Palermo. And, if they don’t, you’ll still wind up here to take advantage of the boundless café and restaurants, bars and nightclubs, parks, museums and galleries, shops and artisanal markets.

Great vibe during the afternoon. If you want to experience this area at it's most vibrant, wait until at least 12 noon on a Saturday and even later on a Sunday. Some of the shops don't open on Sunday.

Beautiful tree-lined safe area of Buenos Aires. My hotel was in Palermo Soho and I’m so glad I stayed there. This was my first visit to Buenos Aires and I had read a lot of travel guides that said the city could be unsafe in some places. Palermo Soho was very safe day and night. It is a very clean and well organized part of the city. There are people on the streets well into the night and so it felt very safe. We had so many restaurants to choose from in this part of the city. We could walk everywhere from our hotel and find an outstanding restaurant. Also, I was there for a tango workshop, and there were several milongas within walking distance from the hotel. Also, it was very easy to hail a taxi in this part of town. I highly recommend Palermo Soho.

Palermo Soho--eclectic and cool--reminds me of NYC Soho, before it became a mall. Great neighborhood for shopping, wandering, lunch. Reminds me of NYC soho before it became a mall. If you are looking for the cool shopping area of BA, you could easily spend an entire afternoon going up and down all of the small streets.

bohemian and upcoming. love this area. very bohemian and upcoming. has an alternative feel to it. nice bars, nice shops, cobblestone streets, trees on the pavement, relaxing and a bit away from the busier centre of the city. beware for pickpockets though.
Wonderful 'barrio' for some walking, shopping and eating.. Wonderful trendy part of downtown Buenos Aires with lots of restaurants, shops, nightclubs, coffee bars etc.
Walk, shop and eat. Walk, shop and eat. Palermo Soho is a cosmopolitan section of Buenos Aires. Enjoy the evening among its streets.

Trendy Neighborhood. Palermo Soho is for sure the most trendy neighborhood in Buenos Aires. It is beautiful and very pleasant to walk on the streets. There are a lot of different stores, nice coffee shops and restaurants.
best neighborhood in Buenos Aires. One of the places in Buenos Aires, lot of places to eat, designer stores. Is a great zone to walk around.

One of BA's hippest places. This is one of the most shi-shi places in Buenos Aires, maybe you could say it's the hippest. It's great during the day for window shopping, or if you want to shop for very upscale clothing this is the place for you. The shops of full of elegant wear, and each store seems to outdo the next for store design. You can find this kind of upscale store design at some 5th Ave shops in Manhattan, but it's not just window dressing here, it's the whole store that has been designed out. One shop after another. Really gorgeous. And if you want to eat during the day there are loads of cafes, pizzerias, and restaurants, particularly around the Plazza Armenia, the center of Soho. There are also lots of very trendy art galleries. The time to really go is at night, when Palermo Soho comes really lively with outdoor restaurants and cafes. A very fun experience. Weekdays are lovely and calm.
Fun, lively neighborhood. Great shopping. Lots of shops feature local artists. Lots of restaurants, bars, and cafes. Very lively and pedestrian-friendly. So much to do.

A place to wander and wonder. A neighbourhood with low houses, lots of restaurants, lots of designer stores and tons of ambiance. During the week-ends Honduras becomes a pedestrian street with an open air market of handicrafts. This was the neighbourhood where Borges grew up as a kid. The trees are ancient and it still retains that feel of a convivial neighbourhood while teeming with tourists. It can be reached by taking the 39 bus (line three with the red placard)
Not cheap at all. There's nothing special there. The prices are high as anywhere else in BA (and that means high!). Just take a walk (and there's no way out, you have to return from some spot).

SOHO comes to BA. Our hotel (see BE Jardin de Escondido by Coppola) was in this neighborhood and it would have gotten very easy to just never leave the area! Right down to the cobblestone streets Palermo Soho has all the charm and I think even a little more something extra over NYC's SOHO. Tons of cool shops, clothing, interior furnishings, great children's clothing, cafe's for coffee and afternoon pastries. There are some nice restaurants and of course what neighborhood like this complete without a lot of beautiful people to watch. Our visit was over a three day weekend that included a national holiday so the streets were a bit more of a buzz with families. There is a park nearby and overall it's a charming area to quiet down a bit.

Best location. This is definitely the best area to stay in Buenos Aires. We like to stay where we are close to restaurants and night life so our after dark commute is short and safe. Palermo Soho is the answer. This is a clean, safe area except for the regrettable graffiti.
Nice area of Palermo. Clothes, design, dining and bars are everywhere in Palermo. On sunny days would be nice to walk in, but I went on a rainy day.

the eclectic areas. this place is a mix of upscale, bohemian and eclecticism...nice places to eat, walk and shop...it has large parks which will be full of groups of ducks and dog-walkers with more than 10 dogs on leashes moving around the,...great outdoor cafes to lounge in....loads of travelers to mingle with and a sever attempt to recreate the atmosphere of NY Soho :)

Not chic, just shabby. There are parts of Palermo Soho that are quite trendy, nice shops, coffee shops, restaurants etc, but I am afraid I could not ignore the fact that it was filthy. I really don't understand how people can ignore the fact that this is a problem. We stayed in a house rented through Oasis Collections called The One, on a small street in Palermo Soho. There is a serious issue with dog mess. I have never seen anything like it in a modern city. There is clearly no policy, culturally or otherwise to clean up after animals and it is shameful.

Another great neighborhood. Buenos Aires as a whole has so many great neighborhoods. This is another example of a unique neighborhood to walk around and explore. There are lots of restaurants all around.
Stroll the streets. Great for strolling and shopping. If your lucky you'll see some tango dancers working for tips. Take a break at one of many outdoor cafes.

A must to know in Buenos Aires. When visiting Buenos Aires this is a must.
Excellent restaurants and bars and designers proposals.
Nice to walk around and feel a different spirit of the city. Trendy while with a very porteño scent.

A charming area with a fantastic vibe. This is a very funky part of town - clearly where the cool kids go to hang out. It's full of great bars, cafes and restaurants, almost all of which call to you to enter as soon as you see them. Deciding which places to drop into for a drink/coffee/gelato is very difficult! There are also lots of cute little shops - cool book stores, clothing boutiques etc. All of this, combined with the cobblestones and narrow streets, make Palermo Soho (and its surrounds for that matter) a very vibrant and interesting place to spend an afternoon.

Not worth the visti. This was supossedly the big shopping area of Argentina. If that is the case then no one in Argentina must go shopping ever. Streets were pretty empty considering the nice spring weather we were having.
Fun and Funky. Great bars, restaurants, and shopping. The trendiest part of town, which in Bs As also means one of the safest if you're traveling alone.

A charming and cosmopolitan fresh look.. It has a charming cosmopolitan fresh look, that enchanted me. Great restaurants and cafes; beautiful people, the European style was very nice. A must visit during your stay in Buenos Aires.
Soho of BA. Funky. Funky mix of small designers and major brands. Great small cafes and restaurants.Safe to walk . Tons of people on beautiful day.

No big deal at all .... I went to Palermo Soho on a Friday noon and found it no big deal at all! The streets around Plaza Serrano were calm and almost empty, with many restaurants and bars closed. The small shops were just small shops, selling items you can find anywhere. A little nostalgia of the 70's, like coming home, walking, after having been to Woodstock ... Something like that. Probably, if you go in the evenings or during weekends, the feeling would be different and much more appealing. One last remark: If you are going or coming back by taxi, ask help for calling a radio taxi whenever possible. Argentinean cab drivers are not at all reliable, always ready to rob you. Pay cash in low denomination notes (AR$ 10 or AR$ 20) and keep your eyes wide open! Any problem, call the police! Give Palermo Soho a try! Enjoy!
Nice neighborhood. Safe funky neighborhood filled with shops and restaurants along Guarracha <sp>. The only thing to look out for is the dog poo left on the sidewalks by the dog walkers.

If you want to shop and eat, that's the place!. I was surprise with the neighborhood Palermo Soho! Very clean, beautiful and safety!
There's many store that you can buy things to your parents and friends, you must go!
If you like Hamburgers, I recommend the "Burger Joint" - Delicious!
My favorite neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Great atmosphere, very trendy and colorful. It made me feel at home. Love everything about this place and I'll certainly come back for a longer visit.

Excellent Place to shop, eat, and drink. An incredible "high class" neighborhood with lots of bars, restaurants, shops, and walks. You can spend hours walking in Palermo Soho.. it is best to know where you want to go and what you want to visit before leaving home. Palermo Soho is a big neighborhood with many places to visit, eat, shop, and drink... If, like me, you don't have a clue, just walk and walk, and walk until you find a place to eat, to shop, and drink... and shop, and shop, and shop.

Lovely place but oh so crowded!. Just a heads up...it is crowded but it is a lot of fun. Lots of fun shops, cafes, restaurants, and street fairs in the weekend. I am glad I made it a point to stop here during my trip to Buenos Aires.

Soho is the place. Love the shopping, restaurants and nightlife in Palermo Soho...I have lived in Argentina for over a year and I visit BsAs often and this area is by far my favorite spot to stay in BsAs

Always a delight. I have seen this place grow and develop every since it started getting trendy in the early 2000´s. It is great to see so many stores, boutiques, cafes, and entertainment in just a few blocks. Go get a coffee at Mark´s (Armenia and El Salvador) and go from there. Can´t miss the soap factory in Borges, the Paper Factory in Cabrera, or Plaza Serrano.
Shopping. Better place to shop and visit ! In the Saturday there are an street market amazing .... In the street are also a lot of stores which fantastic local stores

Great neighborhood. Great area from tourist and general travelers. Transportation access, cafes, bars, restaurants, night life are some highlights. Shopping and small hotels, too. Generally walkable, watch for dog messes and uneven sidewalks.
boho edgy part f the city. is a mix of vintage, with chick and modern. Plenty of restaurants with streets full of character, really nice for a dinner night.

ADVICES FROM A LOCAL RESIDENT. This is the nicest area to visit on Saturdays and Sundays after noon. Before, there is nothing open although you can have lunch in a nice restaurante until shops open. You will find here the same stores that you find on a shopping mall, plus some very local designers -being them the most interesting to be seen-.Very nice ambiance, lots of people walking and draging around. Absolultely a place to visit

good walk,talk,eat,shop. its a nice zone with many restaurants with both local dishes and some international,variety of foods and prices good to fit all budgets. sidewalk cafes, great boutiques,again in all price ranges, artisans sell their wares on weekends. stores open late in the afternoon and stay open until the wee hours. more action on weekends, some nightclubs,great places for drinks, inside as well as sidewalk, which is probably the nicest option offered, very relaxed atmosphere, where you will hear many different languages spoken. totally different from the rest of the city. definitely recommend as we go there often.

Nice walk with many galleries and plenty of restaurant - bar options. Palermo Soho and Palermo Hollywood are 2 areas that shall be visited while in Buenos Aires (BA). I prefer the first one to the second one. Be ready to walk around many streets that have plenty of restaurants, bars and galleries among others. There are some streets that have more flow-environment than others. In my opinion mostly the nice area is located between Av Santa Fe and Av. Cordoba and Av Dorrego and Julian Alvarez. Streets with old rock bricks (or which look like) tend to be most populars (Ejem Costa Rica). Plaza Cortaza is a good start and has a street market during a few days of the week. Also for some reason the further away you walk from the Av. Santa Fe the nicer it gets. For some reason pet excrements and garbage are frequently found on the street close to this Av Santa Fe. On a different note, we did not encounter any unpleasant situation of any kind but you will also find a lot of homeless walking around as sun sets in this area. Enjoy your walk.jr

Great neighborhood. Even though it isnt really close to downtown and most of sights, it was a great place to be in a hotel. We would spend all day walking and at night we get back to hotel and had a lot of restaurants and bars close by. After spending all day walking, it was great get back to hotel, have a nice shower and just crossing the streat to a good dinner.

Great Neighborhood - Live Like a Local. We enjoyed our stay at Oro 2222 (booked through Oasis Collections). Lovely neighborhood, convenient to the best parrillas, a nice shopping mall, grocery stores, and we were able to watch plenty of soccer from our 19th floor balcony. Nothing beyond this is more than a $ 5.00 cab ride away (and have exact change because the cabbies keep the overage...)
Great area. Great area and nice spot to book your hotel. Near Palermo Viejo, this area has nice stores, restaurants, bars and coffee shops. Even if don't stay in this area it's a must to visit.

Best neighborhood to stay and take a peaceful stroll on streets. We booked an apartment in Palermo Soho and stayed for three days. We loved our stay here and took walks on the beautiful streets surrounded with beautiful architecture. The neighborhood has good restaurants, pubs and shopping places.
chic quarters of Buenos Aires. Uptown area With many chic cafes and buildings. good Place for shopping, but other than that nothing much to see.
Shopping in nice small houses. After visiting monuments in the center of Buenos Aires, it is nice to relax and make shopping in Palermo Soho.

Beautiful, and sophisticated neighborhood with it's own unique vibe. This is undoubtedly along with Recoleta the finest neighborhood to visit in Buenos Aires. It is beautiful and there are plenty of good restaurants, and upscale boutiques. It is also reached by public transportation from Recoleta or the Center. It's worth visiting in the afternoon, as well as in the evening.
Gorgeous and unforgettable. Beautiful! the love of maintaining historical buildings is obvious - serious pride of ownership here. Great shops and amazing restaurants. Can't wait to return!
A must see. This is probably most beautiful place in B.A. I really liked Soho with street performers and artists selling their work. It's not a big place but if you're in BA you should go and see it.

Palermo Soho - Upscale Shopping. The upscale shopping and eateries are incredible. No visit to this district is complete without stopping by the Library. An old theator that has been turned in to a library / book store with the same name. Absolutely fantastic.

The best part of the city to stay!. Clean, nice part of B.A, but close to Recoletta and the old city. Also, very close to the good restaurants, nightclubs and bars on the Honduras street.
Bo-Bo hotel is perfect, and the stuff will help You with Your activities
Lively Neighborhood. Lots of restaurants, quaint lighted streets, shops Fun to walk around. Close to Zoo and is walkable (long walk) to City Center
Nice neighborhood.. A charming place with many restaurants, bars and fine stores. There are specialized design home stores. You can walk to Outlets region (about 10 minutes).

Feels like in Berlin mixed with Paris and Madrid .... There are hundreds of nice little fancy shops and Cafés and restaurants and placed to sit outside and enjoy the sun and the flair of one of the greatest places I have ever visited. everybody's so nice and welcoming, almost frightening ;)
A great place to just walk around and look, and sit, and walk and look...

Favourite area in BA. I love this area of Buenos Aires! So many restaurants, cafes, bars and boutique shops. There is a great vibe on the weekends with everyone sitting out on the payment and wandering around. I strolled around for hours!

Beautiful area in Buenos Aires. Great place to stay, shop, eat or drink! Really nice streets, nicely lit at night. Bars and cafés with outside seating - a perfect place to spend the day or night! Would highly recommend.
lively life. Palermo Soho is a very lively and lovely area. Shops and bars, old and new, classic and design. How I love this area! This neighborhood splashes!

great shopping and walking. This is an area with small shops, boutiques, restaurants, cafes, ideal for walking around. You can easily spend a day there. Just make sure you go there when the weather is fine!

Palermo SOHO not so working class anymore. Ex President Marcelo T. Alvear zoned the land this neighbourhood is developed on, to ease the burgeoning population´s need for accomodation. You will notice that the blocks are smaller than elsewhere in the city, and the working class folk were able at one time to be able to afford a home at last. The plaza known as plaza Serrano ( actually plazeta Julio Cortázar) was once the local fresh produce market. As the neighbourhood became gentrified, it slowly changed to include more and more bars, restaurants and boutique shops to eventually become known as SOHO. Tours through the Parks and Plazas of Palermo and Recoleta are well worth investigating to discover this and the other 1/2 dozen parts of PALERMO.

Great day out at the shops. Palermo Soho is a wonderful collection of shops - food, fashion, arts, coffee, etc. Get there at 10 and walk till the sun sets. Choose between some unusually welcoming high end fashion locations and fine food and drinks to fill the day.
Place to shop. Nice shops, clothes and other brands, a very specific argentinian style, nice district during the day.Wew have prefered to stay in Palermo Hollywood for dinner

6 weeks in Palermo Soho. We stayed for 6 weeks in Palermo Soho. What a fabulous neighborhood! A mixture of young and old, married and unmarried. Numerous small businesses featuring restaurants, bakeries, cafes, fruit and vegetable stands dot most streets in the area. The subway is an easy 4-8 block walk depending where you stay (4 blocks or 10 minutes for us) and easy access to the amazing park system in Palermo. Just a fabulous neighborhood that really has all the favorable characteristics of Buenos Aires.
Great Place to stay, shop and go out. Its full of excellent restaurants, and the nightlive there is even better.There are also lots of outlet near it, on Cordoba Av.

Food and shopping paradise. I have been to Buenos Aires a few times and this is my favourite neighbourhood. It is the epicentre for shopping and foodies, in BA. There also numerous bars and clubs. Tourist attractions are more in the Recoleta area but I much prefer Palermo Soho because it exemplifies the laid back Porteno lifestyle. Can't miss
Cool area. I really like Palermo, and Palermo Soho, is very alive when shops and market is going on. Nice old area of Palermo.
The place to be. if you want to visit buenos Aires , palermo is the place to stay and from there you can visit the town. Clean, green, safe.

Trendy but in a funky way.... I didn't spend enough time here to really critique it but the area was filled with interesting shops bars and restaurants. We ended up at a plaza and had a drink upstairs with a great view of the street activity.

Cute stores. Nice boutique shops but not as many as you would think. There are a stretch of shops and then a long stretch where there is nothing, then another restaurant or two. Weird. Also you hear English everywhere on the street except the people that work in the shops and restaurants, and pretty much act like they dont care if they get your business or not.

A definitely must go neighborhood. Palermo Soho is now the #1 tourist attraction in Buenos Aires. You have a lot of good restaurants there, shopping -if you have kids between 4-15 you should definitely go to Ona Saez kids located in El Salvador 4694. Very trendy and original apparel for kids & teens. If you go for a delicious Argentinean barbecue, then book a table at La Cabrera -they have two restaurants there. You should also walk down the streets that are specially busy during weekends, day and night.
a small area with an artistic and romantic atmosphere. It is so nice to walk around this part of the city, with its clean paved streets, its fashion designers shops, its terraces, ...!

A great way to see another side of Palermo. This is a three hour part walking part minibus tour with a guide who gives you an in depth understanding of the development of street art in recent times. This is done by reference to their murals in different parts of the city. The tour ends in Palermo Soho where you will find many interesting shops and restaurants. US 25 dollars well spent.

A beautiful neighbourhood. A great place to take a walk during the day or go dinner or have a drink during the night. Lots of restaurantes, food is not the best in BA but the atmosphere is amazing. Going for a drink or dancing is a must if you want to know the night at BA. If you don't like very mucho the night life you can take a walk during the day and enjoy shopping and having a coffee.
hip and quiet. I only visited at night and had dinner...the shops seem to close early and the restaurants seem to stay open late. Has a nice hip feel to stroll and window shop

nice walk. We went to Palermo Soho one saturday to walk in nice surrounding. We liked the place and would go there again. If I remember correct there was one restaurant called Frida Kahlo. Atmosphere ther very nice.

Bohemian and good shopping. I loved wandering around this neighborhood. There are good restaurants (sadly they weren't open while I was there because I went too early) and you feel like you are in Europe when you walk around. Cobblestoned streets and lots of young people. Loved it.

Fantastic atmosphere. Lovely to just wander around the pretty streets. Restaurants are plentiful and all I tried were excellent. Women are well catered for in the boutiques but men will struggle more.
very bohemian. such a nice area with low buildings, big squares, restaurants, bars , boutiques and shops ... cobblestoned streets and many trees ... a great area of Buenos Aires!
Great shopping. Quality shopping district with competitive pricing, shoes leeather goods, clothing - pretty much all you needLots of places to eat with a variety of foods

A younger side of town. Sort of like Soho in NYC many years ago, this is an area that's trendy (often trashy) and definitely for young folks. Older tourists might not like the graffiti or the distance to many of the main sights, but even though I felt older than most of the people there I enjoyed our stay in this area.

great option to stay in BA safe and full of life. if you like alternative this is the place to be, safe with almost one police officer on each corner, many good restaurants and great variaty of independent designers shops is a great play not just to visit , to stay and ejoy the extic life of Plaza serrano, and if you want a typical meal in a . sotial club where the locals play soccer and learn tango Club Eros is ithe place to go to have a teste of local food a good price ( nothing fancy) but auténtic, another Must go is El Preferido an iconic old Store that works and restaurant and is unique,! enjoy the broadcaste of the 83,3 radio broadcast trough the window, and discover the long range of old cars which are Argetiniain clasics like colectivos ( old busses) or old Utes,
People live here. Nice neighborhood, lots of food choices and safe to walk around at night. Lots of fun dogs. I liked the convenience to the parks.

center of attention. Loads of inexpensive and expensive shopping. Clothing, home goods, shoes, purses, and trinkets. Wide range of eateries in streets lined with London Plane trees. some streets cobbled. Saturday flea market. So we note the positive,. but here is the negative for us: dogs everywhere almost none on leash. In five days saw one person pick up dog droppings. one must be always always on alert - park your shoes at your door as you may track filth into home. Other neighborhoods of Buenos Aires did not have this problem. At restaurants, dogs come to your outdoor table until owner decides to maybe intercede.

Designer quarters of BA. Opt for staying in this area, you will discover nice restaurants, bars, night clubs as well as designer shops, all reasonably priced. Find yourself a nice boutique hotel in the area and enjoy your stay.

Enjoyed our stay here.. We made this our base whilst visiting BA, it is a very friendly suburb and only a short bus or tube ride into the centre of the city.We used the tube at first but it was so hot and busy we reverted to the bus service. We found this much better as the buses go to so many different area's we could explore the city without much hassle. The local restaurants and bars to numerous to mention more than served our needs.

Trendy part of Buenos Aires. A very interesting part of the city but expensive. A bit of a tourist trap, you will hear many nationalities around, good restaurants. But beware pickpockets and mobile phone snatchers!
Loved it. Great atmosphere. Very good service, no problem with English. Best steak I've ever had. Even the salad and bread was great.

Nice Neighbourhood But .... As you stroll through this neighbourhood, the life of a porter comes to life. It is a real neighbourhood with nice houses, and run down houses, cafes, little restaurants, big restaurants, lots of low level shopping and little parks in the middle of busy roundabouts.If you want to be closer to the residents of Buenos Aires, this is more representative than Recoleta, the snooty neighbourhood. If you want to see pretty architecture, go back to Palermo, Recoleta and Retiro. If you like new things, go to Puerto Madero.If you want to see how real people live, this is closer to it then even Boca and San Telmo which are overrun by businesses and/or shady people.Give an hour walk and do some some low level shopping to get a feel for the city but do not expect to be blown away by anything.

On a Sunday afternoon. There's the famous market in Plaza Serrano if you are in that part of town and don't want to go as far as San Telmo.
