Lots of families and young people out enjoying the vibe of which there was plenty. Easy to walk around and soak up the atmosphere. I actually walked back to my hotel near the Mercado de Pulgas - took about an hour but very easy walking.
Great neighborhood!. Palermo Soho has great restaurants and bars. Many options for you to choose and have a great dinner in little outstanding bistros or just a few drinks with friends. Enjoy.

Culture. In this town you can find many cultural places where you can learn a little bit about this country.
Walks and bike rides are wonderful.

cool, chic & cheerful. Fun area to stay and hang out
lots of nice restaurants and boutique..just wondering and lost in the beauty of buenos aires

Spend a day walking through the streets, going to the boutiques and drinking coffee. The streets of Soho are filed with so many local and internationa designer stores all varying in prices. You could spend a day going through them all. Even if you arent shopping to buy - the shops themselves are just beautiful to look at! And definitely stop for a few cups of coffees and some empanagnas on the way!

Hip and Fun. The area has nice shops, bars restaurant and a very bohemian chic feel. Even if you do not want to buy anything just sit and people watch.
More details about our trip can be found at http://bishopworld.wordpress.com

This is the place to be - if you want to feel safe in BA!. The area is beautiful, filled with lovely restaurants, shops and cosy buildings/alleys bordered with trees.
Extremely romantic.
Far better than staying in downtown BA.
Woul never consider another place!
Fun area. Loved walking the streets enjoying the great restaurants and boutiques. It's a real neighborhood - a cross between Soho and Greenwich Village in New York.
Cool area. Not many bargain stops and the selection wasn't really my thing. Fun to walk around and visit. Nice restaurants.
Lovely atmosphere. The whole area of Palermo is wonderful , with such a lovely atmosphere, great restaurants and bars and quirky shops to browse in.

great for shoppers!. lovely unique boutiques for children/men/women's clothing and shoes. Most made in Argentina are beautifully done and in styles which are not like items you would find in the US. Lots of fun to window-shop as well
Spent a week here.. Rented an apartment in Palermo Soho from Oasis Collection. Felt as if we live here. Great street life, restaurants and ambience. Great service..

Palermo Soho. This is a wonderful neighborhood to stroll tree-lined streets, sip cafe, window shop in stylish stores or eat in good restaurants. There are good hotels in which to stay. The Subte makes getting almost anywhere in the rest of BA a snap and after seeing the hustle and bustle it is a relief to retreat to quiet Soho for the evening.

What a fabulous little pocket of the City. Everything you need within walking distance. Streets are abuzz with joggers, walkers, dog walkers, meandering tourists. Walk no more than a block in any direction and you come upon something you didn't even know you were looking for. What a great trendy part of town for shopping and eating.

Hip and chic. Palremo Soho has been a trendy area for many years, however during the past 2 years this area has become even more hip than ever!With the opening of various new Boutique Hotels, Restaurants and Shops, this barrio of BA offer something for almost every one and lives up to its names expectations. However, Soho in New York is a very different experience - but so is New York all together. Do not forget, you are visiting South America, with all the good and bad sides!

Nice neighborhood. This neighborhood is well located, full of bars, restaurants, designer shops, and trends. It is a nice place to hang out and or find good restaurants of any kind. It is well located, but the subways are a bit off. Taxis, anyway are not expensive in the city.

Coolest districe in Buenos Aires. From the cafes to shopping and bar hopping, Palermo Soho is one of the coolest and trendiest districts in the world. Fine and casual dining can be found throughout the cobblestone streets. From October thru April you can sit al fresco and enjoying watching the hip and trendy locals stroll by. Most of the high end Argentine Fashion houses are located throughtout the main streets of Palermo Soho. I truly love this neighborhood and already planning my next visit here!
Great area of town. wonderful coffee shops, tree lined streets, good restaurants, lovely architecture. Investigate everything from the tiny restaurants to the shops.

With the spirit of NY SOHO. Of course this is very far away from NY but Palermo Soho is a very nice place in Buenos Aires, to find designers clothes shopping, amazing cafes and restaurants with excellent grills!!! During weekend is very crowdy and you can feel and sense the youth spirit everywhere.

My favourite neighbourhood. Buenos Aires feels like an old European capital city in a parallel universe, and this neighbourhood has atmosphere in spades. A mix of cobbled streets and designer boutiques, cute cafes and upscale restaurants, the cracked paint and paving stones busted by big old trees give it a faded grandeur that's entirely unique and completely addictive.

I loved this place....... it was my type of place to stay and just amble around.The cafes on a Saturday were full of young BA families and the odd touristWhen I was choosing to stay in BA I chose this area above something more central....I had been at sea for 20+ days and wanted to get away from water for a while....it was an area which had something for everyone, chic boutiques, to late night bars and discosIt was an area of high energy people getting ready for the oncoming summer season
The Area for Travellers. This is the area for travellers. Everything is at your finger tips. A safer neighbourhood and many restaurants and bars are in the area.
Love AR. I like going to Palermo Soho for a relaxing walk around the stores and coffee shops. It's nice to hang out here on weekends and get carried away in the relaxed atmosphere.

Great For shopping!!. Palermo Soho is great! You can shop trendy outfits from famous argentinian designers as well as beautiful shoes and hanbagsThere are also plenty decoration shops in the neighbourhoodIt is fun to visit! It is full of people having lunch or dinner (you have lots of excellent restaurants too!)It is where you can find the best of fashion in Buenos Aires, it is a cheerful and lively place you must not miss!You have great boutique hotels there as well
my district. i cannot imagine to stay in any other place than in palermo soho.. you done have to move anywhere else - here you can experience todo

Delightful area full of restaurants. This is a charming district, worth a walk around for the old buildings and many restaurants. If you are looking for a place to eat in the early evening, that may be a problem, as most seem to open only after 20:00, but we found a pleasant French place to have beer and snacks.

International, trendy and alternative. The vibrant Palermo Soho is one of the trendiest parts of Palermo and Buenos Aires, along with Palermo Hollywood.Especially popular between young upper-middle class Argentines as well as foreign tourists, and much appreciated for its international, trendy and alternative character, Soho is a now an area known for fashion and design boutiques but also a good place to dine or having a drink, due to the high concentration of restaurants and bars. Highly recommended.

place for teenagers and up to early 30s. I was at restaurant El Francés last night (see review. There were 5 restaurants I could see from the street side window, all overflowing. All the young ladies had very short skirts and very long legs. In the restaurant, 2 middle aged couples +, all others youngsters. Generally a place I can easily avoid , and will in the future
Dissapointed. This area would be great for young adults looking for a club scene at night. For us it did not offer much.

Soho - but not as we know it!. An amazing place to wander around at any time of the day or night. Restaurants, cafés, bars at every turn complemented by interesting little boutiques and the odd convenience store. Very handy for the subway and buses into the main tourist areas of the city but also within walking distance of several gardens and the Museum of Decorative Arts. This is our second visit to the area and I feel a third coming on!

so nice to stroll through. İt was before noon, so the shops were already opened. There are lots of things to get curious and to see. The atmosphere is very relaxed and all the cafes on the streets just give you a bit more boost to go on walking and exploring. We found some amazing articles, which will remind us of about our trip to BS AS and Palermo Soho.

Right up my street!!. This neighbourhood is awesome.....was literally walking around for hours, totally immersed in the the most vibrant colours, smells and creativity. Every street is different and just when you think you have found your favourite restaurant. Cafe or boutique shop...another comes along to takes its place. It s one of the safest places in BA but just don't become complacent and always keep an eye on your bag when you are there.

Our barrio. Stayed here for a month and found it great.Superb restaurants, interesting shops, friendly people, a quiet safe barrio.Close to the subte (subway), lots of buses available, a good place to make your base.

Interesting neighbourhood. We came here on the bus (39/3) from the city centre and spent a pleasant afternoon walking aound enjoying the .....how can I describe it?.....upscale bohemian neighbourhood. Lots of boutiques and cafes, nice benches to sit and watch the world go by. We were fortunate to find a cafe in a lovely quiet green courtyard quite by chance and I can't remember the name unfortunately. I think it was on Goretti Street.Worth coming out here, quite a different atmosphere from the frantic city centre.

Trendiest area of Baires. This is the Notting Hill of Buenos Aires. WIth a plethora of bars, restaurants, designer shops and boutique hotels this is no doubt the best area to catch the vibe of the city. During the day it's the trendiest place to go for shopping and coffee and in the evening the bars and cafes are populated by young people, a mix of locals and foreigners. Unmissable if you want to get the spirit of Baires.

Vibrant Neighborhood. Interesting and fun area, especially good for restaurants and some shopping. Nice mix of young & old walking around the neighborhood - and you DO want to walk, it's easy and interesting. A couple of small parks (one under construction/renovation in January), some sidewalk cafe's where you can sit & sip & watch the people. Not a touristy neighborhood, just real people.
Top nice neighbourhood!. Very hip and cool neighbourhood. Lots of great restaurants!! Loved to walk around and just watching the locals, browsing the shops and enjoying the nice restaurants. Love it!
Great area to explore and eat!. So much to see. And sooo many good restaurants. The place is buzzing with people. Such a nice part of town when in Buenos Aires.

Perfectly charming neighborhood. I cannot say enough good things about this neighborhood - you could walk around enjoying the view (beautiful trees, quirky murals and graffiti), getting drawn into shops (so many great shops!), and finding places you want to eat (and eat and eat). Multiple friends recommended staying in a hotel here, and I totally get why now - it's a great place to spend time!
A must. This is a great place to stay! There are restaurants, pubs and bars everywhere! Rent an apartment and get around on foot.The outlet shops are nearby.

Great stay in Palermo Soho. Lots of good restaurants and shops to poke around in. Good location from which to start BA explorations as there are two subway stops nearby. While busy, we found the area quite comfortable and quiet at night.

Great vibe. I have rented a apartment twice in Palermo Soho. The neighborhood is safe and filled with great restaurants and bars. This neighborhood is a short bus or cab ride to other parts of the city so it has a great location. Check out Las Horas on Paraguay and Thames for a great steak.

A taste of London or NY in South America!. This colourful, yopung neighbourhood has not been called "Soho" by mistake. The atmosphere is there, it does definitely remind of London or NY's village. Plenty of bars, restaurants, boutiques. Definitely worth the visit, particularly for young persons. Go there on a week-end, late afternoon or night.

very safe place. It is safe to walk day and night. We have been walking during the last six weeks with no problems at all. Most of the time during late hours. Tons of restaurants and a very friendly environment.
Overrated. I expected lots of trendy restaurants, boutiques, bars, and galleries. There were some, but not as numerous as I expected. And where were the artists, hipsters, cool vibe?

Super cool place !!!. If you like to see the coolest fashion place of Argentina, this is the place, Cool restaurants, with all the variety you want, vegetarian, parrilla argentina, etc, all you imaging with all the decorations possibiliites are here. Is really better than Palermo Holliwood, People is very cool all over the place, Nice to visit on Saturday and Sunday afternoon, because you can see lots of artisans selling their stuff. Nice place to take 3 or 4 hours, walking, shopping and taking something to eat. A great thing to do in Buenos Aires!!
Great place to stay. This was a perfect place for me to stay in Buenos Aires. Travelling by myself, this area felt safe to go out at night and had great little boutiques and cafes and a market too.

A great place to stay and to explore. We stayed at Duque Boutique Hotel and Spa and were treated like we were at home. Every request was exceeded with response. Many enjoyable restaurants were within walking distance.

See all the difference. Palermo Soho is an important place of Bs Aires. I have been here several times during some stays in the city - it is changing fast and lively all the time. There are great shops, designers, restaurants with a very specific atmosphere (and design!) and this is amazing and positive.The markets give you a posibility to find some interesting little things as a souvenir. No one will miss to experience the place I hope.

Read. Palermo Soho is great place for outdoor cafes, restaurants, bars, markets, and shops. To me, it was more impressive at night when the area seemed to come to life. During the day, you can see a lot of graffiti on the buildings which distracts from the area. Also, during my visit the streets needed some sweeping from the litter. Overall, it’s a must area to visit…especially at night.
A must. Yes, if you go to Buenos Aires, a long, leisure visit to Palermo is a must. A slow walk in a warm late spring morning is something to remember.Do not forget your camera.

Cool "a la boheme " restaurant and shopping area. its a cool neighborhood, developed from the base of an old "barrio" that inspired the great Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges, now full of hipster restaurants bars and high end shopping.
Most hotels are small boutique hotels. Great area to use as a base to discover buenos aires in a not so busy area
Great area, real Buenos Aires!. A very nice area, with lots of bars and restaurtants - gives you a real feel of what Buenos Aires is all about.

Great Area. Fantastic shops! Didn't find this area until a couple of days before the end of our trip which was probably fortunate as each and every boutique shop was more beautiful than the one before. Most of them were quite expensive but good quality and fantastic styles. Could quite happily have walked around there for days....

Lovely neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Palermo is a must-see area in BA. The streets are lined with trees and quaint stores, and there are many plazas and parks to enjoy. This area is also filled with trendy restaurants so plan a visit around meal time. I would also recommend staying in this area as there are many apartments that you can rent by the day or the week, and hotels too.

Interesting people, fashion, art and people to see.. Interesting, and very good to explore by foot, you can take the metro to the park and go by foot admiring the atmosphere, enjoying the local stores until the square with good places for a wine/beer admiring the street fair

Palermo Soho is the Place to Be. Staying in the Palermo Soho area allows you the opportunity to walk the neighborhood, shop at your leisure and walk to dinner at the numerous good dinner choices offered to you. It is quaint, lively and beautiful at the same time. This is the area to stay in Buenos Aires.

Bigger everyday. I have known this area for years and I have seen its transformation. Today it is quite "mainstream", with many shops that you find in large shopping malls (I liked it more when it was smaller and you found unique stores and design). But it is nice to see some old building being recovered and transformed into comercial activity. Very good bars in the area. Ideal for a late afternoon walk and shopping spree, followed by a very nice dinner in one of the many restaurants around.

very nice urban neighbourhood.. walk through it on saturday from 11 am until very late in the night. full of nice boutiques, shops, restaurants. Look for a nice terrace. Have a late lunch and visit Plaza Serrano
Great Neighborhood!. This was such a great neighborhood to stay, shop and dine in!I highly recommend it to those who want a lower key experience than the fancy Recoleta neighborhood.
an attractive, safe neighborhood. This is a great neighborhood in BA for walking, shopping, restaurants, cafes, bars. It is comfortable and safe.
cool trendy area but..... Dont go before 1pm because a lot of places aren't open yet which sucks for those early risers. It was a bummer walking around at 1130 am and most stores not even open yet
Beautiful neighborhood. This neighborhood was my favorite around Buenos Aires. Great shops, coffee shops and beautiful architecture.
Plenty of choice. Great neighborhood with lots of bars with outdoor seatings. Lots of variety of food and vibes to choose. Strongly recommended for hanging out at night.
Overrated. Maybe it was because I went there in the afternoon and not in the evening, but it was not worth traveling all the way from my hotel near Plaza de Mayo.
so much fun. Love it all...full of life, great restaurants, gret shopiing, great street art. Stayed at BA Shohotel - strongly recommend, ate at Ceviche great! Ate at Gulie - Aweful - dont go there!

Cool neighborhood to lunch and shop.... I come to BA every year and I like visiting Palermo Soho. There's also Palermo Hollywood (some people confuse the two) which has more restaurants, but can look more abandoned at night. Palermo soho is kind of like what NYC soho/village used to look and feel like. Lots of little boutique shops, larger Argentinian brand names and restaurants to have a coffee, tirada (draft beer) or meal. There's a market at plaza Serrano and another one in another plaza nearby with handmade items. They used to only be there on weekends but I think now it's a permanent fixture. All in all you'll find something to do and can spend an enjoyable afternoon or evening here.

Hip location with great bars, restaurants, wine bars.... Great location with most things in walking distance and lots of little markets to supermarket shopping. Re bars and restaurants and wine bars check out my recommendations here...

Do not eat at Madagascar!. There is a restaurant/bar at plaza Serrano called Madagascar which you should avoid. My husband and I had now clue where to get a quick lunch so we just stopped at this place. The burgers were terrible, the fries were definitely made the day before and the service was the laziest we've ever experienced. Do not eat here!

Lot of shopping, restaurants and bars. Beautiful during the night too. Fashion, all kind of shopping, good restaurants and bar in the heart of Buenos Aires. Nice old streets with trhe modern contrast of new shopping houses.

A lovely week in Palermo Soho. We, a family consisting of three children and two adults rented a really chic house with a small swimming pool for a week in Palermo Soho. This part of Palermo has got lots of small boutiques with all kinds of beautiful clothings - not the kind of clothes you may find on the high street, but truly unique pieces. Night life offers several romantic restaurants with great atmosphere. The only drawback of Palermo Soho is the distance to downtown.
Nice and chic area. We spend some time in Palermo area and in next visit definitely staying in this area as this is the new and upcoming area of BA. Nice trendy bars and restaurants in this area.

It's Where The Fun Is. I've lived in Palermo Hollywood and now Palermo Soho. I love walking out my door and right into the neighborhood. Great shopping on El Salvador and Honduras between Juan B Justo and Scalabrini Ortiz. Restaurants and bars are numerous. The area has a lot of charm to it. The subte stops aren't too far when you head towards Ave Santa Fe. i think it's one of the best places for nightlife in the whole city and I always feel incredibly safe (with using common sense). Plus, taxis are cheap to other neighborhoods, so this is a good base to launch from.

Pretty neighborhood, wrong attitude.. It is one of the loveliest areas in Buenos Aires. Great restaurants, cafes and shops, old trees and houses give the neighborhood personality and charm. The problem is the funny attitude some shop and restaurant's personnel have. They tend to scan the customers trying to find out the spending potential of the subject in question. If they decide one isn't intending to spend a lot, one gets ostracised straightaway or sent to a far end table in an empty restaurant or cafe. I guess the area is victim of its own success.
Very trendy fun area!. Love the area! Safe, fun, trendy. Great clothes boutiques. You are spoilt for choice for great bars and restaurants.
A great place to visit...if you're 18. This is an area that is filled with bars and little boutiques catering to young people. It's not sophisticated and what the shops carry is very trendy.
Nice trendy area. I really liked all of the bars, restaurants and shops that were around. It is a very walkable area and had a nice outdoor market going on Saturday.

Palermo Soho Personal Guiding. Si estás preparando tu visita a Buenos Aires, en particular a Palermo Soho, visita el grupo Facebook PALERMO SOHO PERSONAL GUIDING, donde te guiarán en forma personalizada a buscar alojamiento o si ya lo estás , a armar tu agenda de paseos, comidas, compras y entretenimiento. If you are preparing your visit to Buenos Aires, in particular to Palermo Soho, take a look to PALERMO SOHO PERSONAL GUIDING, when you will be guided to look for lodging, or if you already are there,to make a personalized agenda where to eat, shop or going out.

Best Barrio In Buenos Aires. This is one of the most fun, interesting communities in the big city of Buenos Aires. It is full of restaurants, cafes, night clubs, boutique shopping, historic attractions, plazas and of course the Palermo Woods. Popular with tourists and local residents Palermo Soho is always full of life and excitement. It is very different during the daytime and night time when the lights come alive. The popular weekend market at Plaza Serrano is always a great place to find local arts and crafts at good prices.

cobblestone streets. We stayed in an elegant pent house apartment here and loved every minute of this area. IT is a wonderful combination of residential , cobble stoned and tree lined streets, sprinkled with many great restaurants. What we loved most was the feeling that this area became "our" neighborhood. It has that effect- a combination of Greenwich Village in NYC and an exotic city. Delightful
Trendy neighborhood. Lots of fine shops and all kinds of restaurants. It wery pleasant to walk around in this safe neighborhood.
A very great zone. If you want a place where you can find a lot of restaurants, pubs, and places to have a great time with your family and/or friends, these is the place that you have to visit.

Fun, Fun, Fun. That is Palermo Soho in a nutshell. Great shops, terrific people watching while enjoying a cappuccino in the sidewalk cafes, and the pizza is wonderful. If you like things a bit funky, this is your place in B.A.

trendy cool. cool cafes, boutiques and hours of walking to enjoy!
A trendy area of BA to shop, people watch and the artisan fair on wknds is a must!
Very nice place. Very very nice place to walk and have a peaceful lunch, walk, beers, diner. Full of great choices, and nice people and stores around.

Beautifull Place, Nice and Neat Places to eat, drink and have fun!!!. A nice part of Buenos Aires City, that you can find nice places where to eat, drink, shop and others.- Also, some Gallery art Places could be found here.- A very Nice neighborhood where the charming streets will catch you!! After Office Pubs you can find here to.- People from different lenguages and countries easy to found.-
Don't miss it!!!!!

best neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Palermo Soho is the best neighborhood in Buenos Aires. With many threes, it is perfect to walk, do shopping and eat. The stores is full of young stylists and have many boutique and design hotels.

Nice trendy part of town. Great cafés, safe area for walking around even late. Cafés are open very very late. Trendy hip and happening part of town. Bars are open till late. Nice small stores selling everything from regular stuff to arts and crafts.

Great place to stay / visit / shops / restaurnats. Please we chose to stay out of the city on the visit and have really enjoyed staying in Palermo Soho.
Sort a Kensington meets Chelsea but with rustic feel.

Palermo Soho Again. We are back in our favorite BsAs barrio and as always enjoy its vibrancy of shopping, eating, and walking about. Today they held the weekly arts and crafts market in Plaza Serrano and we happily absorbed the flavor and excitement of the place. Half the fun is just walking about and taking in the sights. The barrio is plentiful with good restaurants covering a broad range of cuisine and prices. There are number of fine small stores which specialize in unique leather goods and clothes. For example, my wife discovered a number of beautifully made purses at very reasonable prices. We always revisit these shops, as we did today, to investigate their new offerings. This barrio is well worth staying at and spending a day or two investigating while visiting BsAs.

A high point .... We just shopped there 2 days ago. Apparently the economy has hit here. There are some worthy shops, but they are far between. One very bright spot is Humawaca (too cow) ~ a designer store for handbags, clutches, wallets, etc. . All items are unique to this store. And of course, we purchased a number of beautiful pieces. El Salvador 4692, Palermo Viejo

Delightful Surprise. Recommended by our guide - we ventured (reluctantly) out of the main tourist center of the city and are so pleased we did! This hip neighborhood is clearly where the trendy people are - store after store of great fashion and local treasures! Cafes and restaurants a plenty! Bring the credit card and do some shopping!

Cozy neighborhood. We recently visited Buenos Aires and stayed in Palermo Soho. With the cozy cafes, tree-lined streets and quaint restuarants, we found we didn´t really need to venture out into other áreas. We were within walking distance to shopping and nightlife. Highly recommend staying in this área!
Really fashion. Argentinian district of fashion, you will have lots of shopping to do. Really nice restaurants to eat in, and not VERY touristic, so there is not LOTS of people.

Great Shopping and Cafes. I loved this area of the Buenos Aires. What I liked best is that the area has mostly one of a kind stores. That is so refreshing compared to the USA where it seems the same popular stores are everywhere!
Like NY Soho. We walked around the area last night and had a wonderful time. Shops and restaurants where busy with lots of peopl, young and our age. I would highly recommend this as a go to spot.

To spend some good time. Inside Palermo's neighborhood you can find a lot of bars, pubs and restaurants where you can experience various foods. Also you can purchase clothes and other stuffs for your home. All this places are around many streets, like Armenia, Honduras, Thames, Malabia st, and so many more. You can take a rest in Armenian square. Dont' forget to try the best coffee in Buenos Aires visiting Lattente, in 1891 Thames st. If you wanna try great hamburguers, you must visit Burger Joint, Negroni or Sugar Bar. Live the exprience.

Wonderful walk, just don´t expect NY SoHo. Buenos Aires´s Palermo SoHo, is a great plan. The best way to enjoy the neighbourhood is to make a combination of walking arround, looking at its shops or if it is a weekend, the artisan market in Armenia Plaza (Intersection between Armenia St. and Costa Rica St.), and after the walk, make a stop in one of its wonderful "Resto-Bar". You can find almost any kind of food there from burgers to began style food. If you miss home you will find a "Pain quotidien" and a "Starbucks" cofee there too. Saturday afternoon is the moment when the place explodes with people, specially if the weather is nice... arround 7pm people from the city gather arround the plaza to eat something and grab a beer. If you want something more relaxed, the mornig is all yours. This is a nice walk for everyone visiting Buenos Aires, you´ll love it.
Great eating and boutique shopping area. Very nice neighborhood, Lot of great restaurants and stores. There is also an outlet area where main brands offer last year goods or discontinue items.
A cool part of BA. Buenos Aires is an amazing city with so much to see and so many different areas to visit. Palermo Soho is supposed to be one of the coolest neighbourhoods in the city.

Saturday creative markets. What a great way to spend Saturday afternoon in Buenos Aires. On the intersection of Honduras and Jorge Luis Borges there is wonderful market with many varied stalls from : leather goods, adult and children's clothing, handmade jewellery , a miriad of knitwear, toys and items suitable for an Argentinian souvenir.When you have finished browsing the stands, there is a number of cafes for coffee and/or a meal where you can either sit inside on a cool day or outside to enjoy the sunshine.All in all a wonderful experience and a great way to spend an afternoon

Funky location in BsAs. We didn't stay in Palermo Soho, but found ourselves there a few times, I'm pretty sure Palermo Hollywood is next to it, the whole area was great and the only place I could find a flat white, that's a coffee if your not from Australia. The are seemed to have a good mix of cafés, restaurants, bars, local grocers and a good mix of shops, a lot better than walking down ave Sante Fe, which has pretty much all the same shops most big cities have and become desperately boring and over priced

It is like a Soho but without buildings. Palermo Soho is a great place to walk around during the weekend, with nice and creative stores to visit, excellent restaurants like La Cabrera, beautiful people and ice cream stores. You can spend a whole day walking and do not see time goes by.
FUN shopping. Found great stores, bought some nice gifts. Adorable place to shop and eat. Cobblestone and tree-lined streets.

Palermo Soho is the Place to Stay. We stayed here for over a week and could not be more in love with our location. Lots of great restaurants to chose from, things to do, designer clothing stores, and nightlife (Gay and straight). It has a bohemian atmosphere that just gives Buenos Aires a uniqueness that I have not seen elsewhere. Enjoy!

Safe and Friendly. You will feel like you are in a familiar neighborhood after only an hour or so here. But don't worry, you will want to spend more time there than that. We stayed in Palermo Hollywood and walked to Soho about once a day for a week. Very safe.

Upscale. This is one of several leafy, chic neighborhoods outside if the center, all of which seemed pretty much interchangeable to me. Elegant buildings, chic boutiques, pretty cafes. Keep an eye open for the professional dog walkers in the parks. I've always thought that one of the great pleasures of owning a dog was walking it. Portenos disagree.
palermo soho. Great area to stay in . MAny restaurants and bars in the area, very safe and friendly neighbourhood.

Awesome neighborhood. I used to live just outside of Palermo Soho and often ended up here with friends or solo for the evening. Lots of restaurants/cafes/bars, shops and entertainment options in the area. Definitely worth checking out.

Happening place (goes strong late into the night). Lots of shops, food and vibrant crowd. Not much to dislike if you are interested in shopping and nightlife. It is heavily geared toward young adults but that did not bother my wife and me ( we are seniors ). It's a large area, very clean and a good mix of modern storefronts and traditional architecture.
living the soho life!. While in BA i stayed in Palermo Soho, I'm a New Yorker so it made feel at home! Especially with the dog crap all over the place!

Hipster. This place is like Brooklyn, very upcoming area with lots of cool restaurants and boutiques stores. For shopping this is heaven, specially traveling with the family. During the weekend can get very busy but during the week is very calm.
An easy going place. Full of nice places to eat. If you like shopping spreads, then this is the place in BA. Perhaps too many people on weekends.

Shopping, Restaurant, Bars.... and happy people around. Join Palermo Soho for a sunny afternoon or a long night full off nice shops, restaurants and bars! Stayed there 4 weeks without feeling boring etc.

Uber Cool Shops. BsAs is the fashion capital of Central and South America and you will find new and innovative original Art to Wear here. Tons of great restaurants and artful window displays throughout Palermo Soho. Regional Artisans meet in the Square to show their wares on weekends.

Cool spot to relax and have some drinks. Specially at Sundays, when there are some artisans shops openned and the place get really alive, Palermo Soho is a great place to walk by, sit at some bars to have beers or wine (you can also choose just one charming place to spend the whole night). The artisans shops give the place a cool atmosphere and you can find some great things to buy at very good price (women accessories, paintings, clothes). There are pubs, italian restaurants, charming restaurants with many food options. I recomend Sheldon, at Plaza Serrano: amazing ambience with jazz shows, good wine and reasonable price.

The hip area of BsAs. Palermo Soho (south of Honduras), Palermo Viejo and Palermo Hollywood are the hip areas in BsAs. Lots of restaurants, bars, trendy shops and places to stay. All three areas are next to each other and they are easy to get around on foot. The vibe is generally for younger adults, but seniors can enjoy the energy of the areas.

was not worth the hype. La Boca was much more authentic and colorful place to visit - Palermo Soho is a wanna be Greenwich Village in NYC. Overpriced restaurants and shops - was not sure what the hype was about...

Shop and Style. If you are looking for a cool place to have a lunch, brunch, and then go for a little shopping.... then Palermo Soho is THE spot. Cool and relax, you will see a very artistic side of Buenos Aires
Young and lively. The area around plaza Serrano is excellent for an evening walk and then drinks or dinner in one of the chic bars and restaurants.

Nice Neighborhood. It is a very nice place to go at the afternoon, bars, restaurants and shopping. The neighborhood of Palermo Soho has a great atmosphere and offers a lot of things to do if you enjoy discovering places and walk this will be a great experience have desserts cups of coffe, beers or dinner as well.

Oh, to be 30 something again. Mixture of Greenwich Village and NY Soho this is the place to be if you are single or young married. Boutique hotels, great places to eat and interesting shopping. Meander around on a bright Sunday afternoon and enjoy another side of Buenos Aires !

Good to go for dinner. This is a very nice place to go for dinner.
But I suggest to look for a restaurant before to there.... Usually it is crowded, and some restaurants are full and you need to wait for a free table.

Eat at La Carrera. I loved Palermo Soho, it is a very trendy area of Buenos Aires. If you are there you must go eat at La Carrera and order a steak. The food is inexpensive and fantastic. There is also a very nice mall and beautiful botanical garden nearby.

The new area of the city. This area is the new develop zone for shopping, restos. Very busy during sunny weekends, hard to find a table after 2pm. Great feeling of eating seating on the street however 50%. Of the restaurant are tourist traps. Be carefull where you eat. Almost all of them are expensive, only few are recommended. However nice to have a drink, seating under the sun on the best zone.

Great neighbourhood to explore. I really enjoyed walking around this neighbourhood. So many cool cafes/restaurants/bars/shops to explore. It has a trendy/young vibe but not pretentious. It seems to be a good mixture of locals and tourists hanging out there. Recommmend stopping by when in BA.

I live here. Lovely neighbourhood. New buildings and old houses, cobblestone streets, trees and small green parks. Lots and lots of shopping places, clothes, desing, unique objects, handrafts goods, a hippie market all together with restaurants, bars, coffee shops, dancing places, opened until 3am!! Cute tables in the street for breakfast, brunch and tea. You will always have fun at Soho
Great nightlife. Lots of bars, pubs and discoteques everywhere.You can see the latest in fashion.You can get in the mood very easy.I dislike you can't park somewhere near, you have to take a taxi.
Wonderful neighbourhood. a great place where to stay for your holidays, business, etc.Most of the best bars, pubs and restaurants are around Plaza Armenia in Soho.
Cruising in Palermo. Palermo Soho is a great area full of unusual and individual shops and restaurants - just a nice place to browse and relax.

Vibrant area with some wonderful streets to explore.. An afternoon walk or early evening wander in this area is really worth it. The streets are buzzing with people during the weekend, but can be dead if you are there at the wrong times. The buildings are great and the window shopping can be marvelous. The clothes inside the shops were not great - especially men's fashion. The area promises a little more than it offers. If you are there for cafés and chilling then it is perfect.
Interesting BUT. Described as the SOHO of Buenos Aires and certainly worth an hour or two. One of the better and quality parts of BA with restaurants, shops, fashion etc.
i loved this part of buenos aires. i really loved this part of buenos aires the modern styles and the shops are pretty unique! not to miss out!

Cute Stores, Great Interior Design, But Fashion Disconnect. We enjoyed our half day or strolling the stores in Palermo Soho, the Soho of Buenos Aires. The stores were brilliantly designed, each one cooler than the first, but in the end the merchandise did not live up to our expectations as far as innovative or wearable design.
A must see!. Palermo Soho is different from anything you've already seen. It's warm, full of colors, restaurants, pubs, shopping, handcraft itens, etc. A very pleasant walk through there.

Quiet neighborhood not far from downtown.. Great neighborhood to visit by foot or on bike. Bike paths available throughout Soho. Lot's of boutique shopping and nice cafes. Recommended stop for all travelers visiting Buenos Aries.
Beautiful Neighborhood. Very good to take a walk a have some drinks. Many restaurants around, including Crizia, Mott and La Cabrera.
Bohemian, safe and a great bar or restaurant around every corner. Great place to base yourself while staying in Buenos Aires. Loved the choice and variety of bars and restaurants around every corner.
Best neighborhood to stay in BA. Trendy, European, thoroughly safe on the streets at any time. As much as a refuge from the urban crush of BA we could find.
Trendy and chic, but a bit rusty too!!. This neighborhood is full of life at night, due do its restaurants and bars...Palermo Soho has many design hotels too!!
Very pleasant area. It really has the atmosphere of the New York Soho, maybe more exclusive than the original. Good places to drink, eat, have a coffee or party. Or just walk around.
Trendy Neighborhood.... Not only bars and restaurants you can find in Palermo, but also trendy stores, bookplaces, nightlife, etc..
Fun!. Great restaurants, bars, and a huge variety of shops. You can walk around to different places. Restaurants get busy at 9ish. The bars stay open super late.

Great Place to walk. Pleasent place to walk and shop.
Nice cafés and stores with unique clothing Style
My kids loved the streets and nice houses.

great for young adults. Like Lower East Side (NYC) a decade or two ago. This place has a bunch of boutique shops and great restaurants to try. I stayed right at the edge of Palermo SoHo and had a great time here. If you want to rub shoulders with locals this is the place to be.
Eat shop eat shop eat shop. design buffs would love Palermo (all its parts), also foodies and people who love to explore on foot...a beautiful part of the city.
not to miss. wow a great place to go and see places restaurants and the like buenos aires is at its best i really recommend going to palermo

if you want to mix with locals; this is the spot. Travelers have a nice mix of local restaurants and cool boutiques to check out. When you walk around, you walk next to Argentines that are heading to work or going out to dinner with family. Some of the ritzier parts of the city don't offer this argentine experience. And the food is cheaper, better, and there is better people watching in this area. This is my choice of spots in the city to hang out, relax, eat and explore.
Fantastic Suburb!. Briiliant place to stay - young, vibrant, fun and great restaurants! Shopping is also fantastic - lots of fab little boutiques.
Very Cool!. Lots of people walking around, eating, drinking, hipster restaurants, stores, etc... You should spent you day here, defintely. And enjoy your night.
very nice area. Really nice area, colourful and interesting bars, cafés, shops and restaurants. Had a really nice day just wandering around.
Interesting neighborhood. Interesting neighborhood. Nice place to walk many small design shops and restaurants. Outlet stores in the area.

Upbeat Neighborhood. Palermo Soho is worth a visit during a trip to Buenos Aires. The entire neighborhood is upbeat. It is full of interesting boutiques selling a vast array of items--clothing, gifts, crafts, household items. This is the new restaurant scene with many excellent places to eat for lunch, dinner and afternoon snacks. There are quite a few nice coffee houses serving light lunches and afternoon cakes, sandwiches and salads. There are weekend open air markets that bring out crafts people with local made crafts. We stayed in a boutique hotel in Palermo Soho making it very convenient to enjoy this upbeat neighborhood. One caveat, the action does not really take off until at least the early afternoon at lunch time, since most shops do not open early. Most stay open late, making the area full of life late into the evening. The area is accessible by subway and bus. Due to the people out and about, the area is very safe.

nice area with great nightlife. I rented a nice loft in this area as recommended by reading other people´s posts and after having walked around a bit, it is the right choice. Great quiet neighborhood feel in the day, and by night time, it changes and becomes this party town with amazing energy. Wide variety of cuisine in walking distance. Never bored!
Quite a social experience!!. If you choose to go on a weekend, you can see people from different countries, locals and foreigners. Art, lots of restaurants and "cafes" and good quality merchandise.
Lovely area. I really liked staying in Palermo Soho. So many nice restaurants and bars. Felt really safewalking around on my own

Super nice place to go in BA. Bars, clothing, ice-cream, tourists, design, go food, shops and more tourists…this is Palermo. Is the latinamerican version of the NY Soho and has nothing to envy to the original one. Must go.

A must see. The area offers a wide array of restaurants and great stores displaying high quality merchandise. Prices are a little above average as compared to other neighborhoods. Try going on a weekend or public holiday to enjoy the attraction on its full extension as visitors from all nations also add to the local vibe.It may be difficult to park so your'd better use public transportation.

fun walk, people watching. It may get crowded on weekends especially in good weather. Lots of great bars, clubs and restaurants. Shopping too. A favorite with young crowds, fun for people watching and just walking around.

Great place to walk around during the day. Lots of nice interesting shops and cute coffee shops each with there own charm. Took a Argentine friend who lives there all her life and she could not believe how nice it was!
Cool and trendy. Very hipster area. There are lots of bard, restaurants and night clubs. Also great for shopping. During the week if bit empty but weekends are great.
Shopping and more shopping. If shopping is what you are planning to do, there are stores everywhere you turn. somewhat overwhelming but great for window shopping as well. Not the cheapest stores here

New Yorkish neighborhood. Stayed in Palmero SoHo for 4 days. Enjoyed it's quiet streets, smart boutiques, and great cafes.Especially Don Julio's (see review on that one!); Hubby found a fitness center nearby, and everything else you can think of too...just wander around and breath it all in...just be aware that they DO NOT pick up their doggie poop! ...just have to watch where you walk!!!

Best area in Buenos Aires. I stayed in all different parts of Buenos Aires and this is without doubt the best!Cosy, chic, modern but still with a historic touch, what was there before. Lots of restaurants, bars, wineshops, cafe´s in all different pricerange. From a cheap but fantastic burger to the best meat and wine, there is something for everyone. And during the days there are lots of shopping from both the big brands but also small independent designers. This is really an area for everyone!!And compared to Palermo Hollywood, so much more relaxed.Enjoy!

My favorite area in Bs As. Colourful and lively, and yet residential & peaceful neighbourhood. Tons of great restaurants, bars, coffee corners, plenty design clothing stores and green areas. Don't miss this part of town when visiting Buenos Aires.

Hip and vibrant part of BA. There are exceptional restaurants with almost every cuisine offered. The Saturday market is vibrant but different than the well organized Recoleta market that appears to be a bit more gentrified and caters to a different crowd.
Amazing!. Our highlight of the Trip was exploring this part of town during the Sunday Market! Amazing performers, architecture & culture in all directions!

Excellent neighborhood. One of the places of Buenos Aires. The neighborhood si safe, beautiful, fun, full with cafés, restaurants, shops and nice people. Every place in here is great. Also, the best hotel boutique in the zone: Bo bo hotel y restaurant.
Best place to be. If you want to see the most fun area of BA in terms of nightlife and shops, but also one of the most touristy (and therefore a bit pricier), definitely check out this area!

Want to go drinking on a patio with friends?. Here there are many patio restaurants that accommodate a vibrant night-life. The cobblestone road is a nice touch to the experience, it makes it feel more homey. Cars aren't going fast but the life sure is! SoHo as in south of houston, after the neighborhood in New York. The government took actions to stop parts of the city from being named after parts of other cities, but it's still called Palermo SoHo.

Outstanding Neighborhood. We always stay in Palermo Soho whenever we go to BA. It is a vibrant neighborhood populated by good restaurants, great leather and clothing stores, as well shops operated by local designers. We always use this as our base of operations and find it is convenient to explore not only this neighborhood, but also others in the city.
Buenos Aires - Hipster Style. Best shopping, restaurants, and social atmosphere. It is the perfect home base for a trip to Buenos Aires.

Great for dining out. Palermo Soho is a great place for shopping exquisite souvenirs but also offers a multitude of excellent restaurants nearby. You can eat Italian meals or real Argentinian asado. The prices are very economic. I paid for a great meal at lunch time around 40 Pesos (which are just 3 Euro converted with Euro Blue) plus drinks.If you have time, go there for a lunch or in the evening.
Delightful area. We are so glad we chose to stay in Palermo Soho. The area has lots of boutiques and good restaurants. It's safe and convenient. Fun area for shopping!
A must go. it's one of my favourite places in BA. I enjoy walking down the streets to find new restaurants and stores. It's a young, joyfull neighbourhood.

Lost of restaurants and shops. Known to be the nicer part of BA. Lots of restaurants and shops. We stayed in this part of BA for two weeks. Close walk to lots of restaurants or take a taxi to where you need to go. Nice, but nothing special in my opinion. Portenios seem to love dogs and you'll see people walking them a lot, but having said this, I felt the streets were filled with flees or something! Streets are bit dirty and smelly and you'll need to watch out for the water dropping off the air conditioners if you visit in summer.
Chic and sophosticated City. Wonderful area, polite and helpful people. I felt very safe any time I walked around during the day and night.

Honeymoon and 1st Anniversay. Excellent place to relax and just hang out with plenty of excellent restaurants, bars, coffee shops, shops for just about anything including great wine. The best part is with the exchange rate of dollars to peso in Argentina, a great bargain too!,
The Place to be. I found the best restaurants and shops there. I came back many times during my stay , highlights : Plaza Serrano . Plaza Serrano Market on Saturday afternoon really good!

NIGHT LIFE !. Here is night life's heart of Buenos Aires. We had gone there for dinner nearly 22:00 like manny people do. You can eat tables in the street and then after 12.00 clubs are getting crowded but night life comes top around 02:00. The meals are all right and the night fun ise impressive. You should go here at least 1 night. Also you can go there by taxi from the microcentro. It takes 20 min and costs you around 10 usd.
Fun place, the market especially. Lots too look at! There was a market on Saturdays, so you could buy so many things! Maybe your dog needs a new outfit? Or your husband needs a new belt?

Great shopping and cafes. We had intended to stay in this neighborhood, but the owners of the apartment at Malabia 2154 (a Palmero Soho loft/#247592 on an homeowners rental site) told us that the apartment wouldn't be available after we arrived in Buenos Aires and left us stranded, so we ended up staying in Recoleta, which was also nice. The stores and cafes in Palmero Soho definitely have a hip, young vibe, but the neighborhood is great no matter what your age. It's a good place to hang out, and Palmero is the largest barrio in BA, so there are more Portenos than tourists at least when we were there in April that was true, which was also nice. We visited Palmero Soho, Hollywood, Recoleta, San Telmo, La Boca, and Puerto Madera and found them to all be great in their own ways. Buenos Aires is a vibrant, friendly city.

A very different area - don't miss it. Stayed in a hotel nearby (Duque hotel), and loved the area. Very cool, relaxed, great designer shops and good variety of wonderful restaurants. Some coffee shops place chairs on the sidewalk under the green trees - I had a very nice afternoon - reading and watching locals going by.

Really Cool Area... A really nice area to walk around in Buenos Aires. Delicious restaurant/food options and clothing stores. If you're staying in a hostel, I recommend searching for one here. Head to the juice bar (The Factory) for some great fresh juices and Burger Joint for some bomb burgers.
The gastronomic neighbourhood. The most exciting place to spend your nights in Buenos Aires. The Calle Baez is full of good restaurants.

trendy neighbourhood to visit in Buenos Aires. Soho Palermo is a great place to visit in Buenos Aires, also a great place to stay if you're looking for somewhere more tranquil away from the hustle and bustle of central downtown. Soho Palermo is easy to get to by bus from the main city, the number 59 stops at Plaza Italia or the number 39 stops on Costa Rica Avenue in the heart of the Soho district. You can also get the the Green line, D, Subte train to Plaza Italia. The area is really quaint and charming with lots of small unique boutiques, trendy shops, books shops and it seems a cafe, bar or restaurant on every corner. It's such a lovely, safe, neighbourhood to wander, you could easily spent a whole day there soaking up the atmosphere and enjoying the ambience of this fine area.

I just love it. I stayed at Recoleta area but I moved from one place to other to visit the city. I was impressed about how big is Buenos Aires and the differences between one area and the other. Fortunatelly I had a local guide who explained everything to me and we did different things around the city including a stop at this area with some wine tasting at a local bar. Very vibrant full of designers, creativity and bars and restaurants.
very cool. This area is filled with restaurants that have lovely patios for dining and people watching. The streets are filled with people and there is a lot of variety of food choices.

The place never sleeps. Have you ever walked into a place at 4 am an wondered whats wrong with the people? This place is one of those places that never sleeps, we went there at about 3 am, and the place was packed with people, and the restaurants were still serving dinner and beer! what an amazing atmosphere to be in. I would have certainly wanted to spend more time there; but we had limited time in BsAs.
The best part of Palermo. There is no better place to be in Buenos Aires, or Palermo. It is the heart of Palermo, and if you visit Buenos Aires it is the area where you have to stay.

Fun and pretty but watch out for violent robbers. My friend and I had a wonderful afternoon in Palermo Soho. Imagine how surprised I was when I was suddenly grabbed from behind in broad daylight on a busy street, thrown to the ground and had my watch ripped off my wrist. My friend got her head bonked when she tried to get the guy off my back and tore his shirt. He was brought down by a group of angry citizens a block away. A very kind film actor by the name of Gerardo Romano happened to be a witness and helped us and protected the robber from the lynch mob.With only four hours before we had to leave for the airport for our flight home, the police detained us in an endless process. One cop slipped my watch into his pocket. I took a picture of him and called him on it.Without the actor's help we would never have been allowed to leave. We were then chased down the street by the press when we were finally allowed to leave. I have followed the media reports and learned the guy was released from jail after 12 hours and that he had already been involved in 3 crimes in the area, one at gun point. There is a lot of outrage among the population about the lack of crime control in the city. They tried to pick pocket my husband in a restroom by spraying his shirt with some gunk and pretending to "help!" So, great city, wonderful people, but I am not sure there is even a basic level of safety.

Interesting, charming, sense of personality. No, that wasn't a description of me! We checked this area out all by foot and it was really nice. We had lunch at a little cafe outside and people-watched for a little while. The shops, cafes, and vendors all added to the charm of this area and gave some insight into a deeper Buenos Aires than you may find on a city tour, etc.Take some time and check it out.
Lovely area to wander during the day. Lovely casual area to wander around. Nice designer shops not too expensive. Nice restaurants and cares to sit in the sun with a coffee or beer and people watch.

Unique Area Great For Dining And Shopping. We stayed at a condo in Palermo Soho for two weeks. If you are looking for an old residential neighborhood with few high-rise buildings and loads of great restaurants and shops, this is the place. If you stay here, there's little reason to leave the area; if you're elsewhere, it's definitely worth the time to visit -- particularly to avail oneself of its great restaurant selection.

Great for shopping and a real nightlife experience!. During the day, the place offers several good options for shopping and dining. Overall, shopping is relatively inexpensive and unique labels are available. Dining options are plenty and on the cheaper side. At night, from Thursday to Sunday, the streets are filled with partygoers and the vibe is great at many of the bars, etc. It is advisable to go in groups and not alone at night.
hipsters, shopping, good food. I love this part of BA, for its charming streets, nice cafés, and boutique shopping. Especially go for burgers at Burger Joint, and walk around with an ice cream after.

A perfect Saturday afternoon. Lovely shops pepper the cobblestone streets. Lots of local and independant stores that are beautifully presented.Restaurants and cafes alternate between the shops, so you can shop and eat and shop some more.Easily walkable, the area is not that large and packed with options. A great choice for a weekend day.

Hip, interesting, fun neighborhood. Was it because we were in Palermo Soho over a holiday (Carnaval) that the neighborhood was stuffed with street fairs? Between people-watching, dining, shopping at cute boutiques and the street fair, and wandering through small parks, Palermo Soho gave us plenty to do and see.

Great shopping. There are lots of shops with local designers. The prices are very good, and it is interesting to see fashions created in Buenos Aires. Most of the shops had English-speaking personnel so there was no language problem.
Great nightlife. During the day the street market and shops are very creative, and during the night there are many places to drink and have a good moment with friends.

beautiful, artistic, safe. Best in the city, very artistic shop windows, nice places to have a coffee or a glass of wine. There are good quality and expencive unique clothes as well as creative gift shops, but the shopping is not the main attraction there, it is a great place to strall.
Stylish. We loved going for the market in the palmeros area lots of stylish boutiques and eateries around.it's mostly a residential area and nice to walk around.
Nice area - bars restaurants and lively. Went to a bar/restaurant called Madagascar where they played classic rock music. Very lively on a Saturday night

Great Area - Walk it - Shop and Dine. Palermo SOHO is developing into an outstanding neighborhood with wonderful shops and restaurants. I see this area becoming one of the better neighborhoods to live in the future as development in the area continues. Palermo Hollywood although not as many shops is also exciting.
Viejo Palermo. Palermo Soho and other "cooooool" epithets Palermo has received in recent times, cannot altogether hide that it used to be a poor and depressing suburbial neighborhood.

Great shopping. Great shopping and wonderful character. Shops tend to be geared towards the young hip crowd but there are shops there for everyone.
Market day can be very busy and I would suggest the San Telmo market is so much better.

Nice shopping district. You can find several clothing stores there, most of them offered different clothes from local designers. You can find some eating places there or go to Palermo Hollywood for more variety of restaurants.
Restaurants, shops, bohemian/stylish urban feel. Spend days exploring and savoring the atmosphere here. There is no better place to spend your time or money in Buenos Aires.

Wide Variety & Lively. What we found interesting, was the wide variety of cafes, bars, restaurants and boutique shops in many of the streets, as we walked around by day and by night. The whole place is very lively at night, particularly in Plaza Cortaza/Serano and Gorriti. We never felt unsafe walking around at night.If you are interested in fine dining at a reasonable cost, there are some very good restaurants in Gorriti, including "Crizia" at Gorriti 5143.

Charming, upscale neighborhood. This was our favorite neighborhood though it is a taxi ride away from El Centro and San Telmo. The neighborhood has some old charm and is a lively "happening" place as far as restaurants, cafes and clubs are concerned while still being a quiet safe neighborhood.

shopping district. This area was recommended by a local guide. It was filled with boutique stores and restaurants. We enjoyed sitting outside for lunch on a beautiful summer day. But after that, we quickly got bored. Unless you want to shop for clothes or shoes, not much to do here.

Adorable area. We stayed in a lovely 2 bdrm/2bath apartment in Palermo Soho and were very pleasantly surprised at how cute this area is. Lots of trendy boutiques, coffee shops and restaurants to explore on small quiet cobblestone, tree lined streets. After each day tromping around the big city to see the sights, it was wonderful to return home to our quaint area and we felt completely safe here. We took a cooking class here, too.

Old Palermo reborn!!!! Must See...... Yes, for all of you NYC people out there think of the West Village in the 70's and then FLASH you arrive in 2014.... Yes, Palermo is reborn into a beautiful urban area with lovely, restored homes, restaurants and shops! We loved it and highly recommend it to anyone.

A Great Place to stay in Buenos Aires. We have rented an apartment in Palermo-Soho and we have had considerable time to walk, shop and explore the neighbourhood. Look here for a safe, interesting and convenient location to reside while you are visiting BA.

Good Restaurants. It´s a nice neighbouthood to have a walk in the evening (during the weekends) and enjoy a good meal in one of the many located there.La Cabrera is definitely one of the best choices of restaurants in Palermo and in Buenos Aires.

Not as interesting as we had been led to believe. Maybe we are too old but I just didn't get the vibe. Tatty, boring shops selling tatty looking clothes. Grafitti everywhere and watch out for the dog poo. The area is so run down as is a lot of Buenos Aires and is probably a shell of it's former self. No comparison to Greenwich Village in NYC. Good luck to all the new young inhabitants.
good shops. Nice selection of local designers and home goods. Take a break at one of the many cute cafes or restaurants in the neighborhood.

Great area for shopping and dining in BA. The area teems with boutiques and small restaurants that offer a view of BA past, present and future. Spend a day in the area and enjoy the energy of a happening part of this wonderful city.

Very nice, but for tourists... . The neighborhood is nice and tidy, but does not full represent what Buenos Aires has to offer. There many great hotels and restaurants in Palermo Soho, but many tourist traps also (by the way, the trip advisor app for Buenos Aires is great and a must have).

Watch out below!. We booked a lovely house in Palermo Soho. An area with a Greenwich Village vibe to it. Sort of. The dog poop all over the sidewalk is pretty intense. Keep looking down is good advice. We found ourselves walking back home in the streets after our late night roamings. It just seemed safer on the shoes. The upside was good shopping, excellent restaurants and some of the best graffiti in BA.

If you are up for a late night this is where you want to go. You can go at 11pm to have dinner or you can go at 2am and it's exaclty the same. You will probably have to wait at 2am as if it's 2pm...Everybody is outside (in the summer of course) most of the places have sitting outside, people just hang in the street and chat.The stores are funky stores kind of like a Brooklyn , NY area. The icecream store is open til 4am and there is always people online. It seems like nobody works in this city. There is always people up so late!This area is more for single people I believe.

A New Experience on Every Block. After much research we chose accommodation in a sweet apartment in Palermo Soho. This neighbourhood is full of a great variety of restaurants, shops, small and large grocery stores, vegetable and fruit shops - some good and some not so good. Every block has something different to offer. We walked everywhere in this barrio and always felt very safe, even late at night. Beautiful parks and Plaza Italia are only a few minutes walk. Subway or subte from Plaza Italia station to the Obelisk in the centre of the city is less than 25 minutes for a meager 35 pesos a person. Sidewalks could use a serious sprucing up. The concrete is broken and missing in lots of sidewals on nearly every block. And watch out for the dog poop which is abundant some days. But I would come back to stay again without a doubt.

great area - quiet and accessible with a lot going on. We stayed in Palermo Soho in January 2014 and really enjoyed the area. During the day, south of the main street its incredibly quiet and laid back with lots of little cafes and stores along the streets below a lot of old and a number of new apartment complexes. As the day turns from late afternoon to early evening (about 8-9 PM), peoples come out of the woodwork to go to the numerous local bars and restaurants that are on virtually every street corner.The northern strip of the neighborhood provides easy access to the subway (although we recommend avoiding rush hour - before 10 AM and 4-6 PM), and the area is walkable to Palermo Hollywood and Recoleta.

Nice, but don't reduce your Bs As experience to this.. Palermo Soho is certainly nice for one afternoon stroll. But reducing a city as rich in history and culture as Buenos Aires to this is absurd: beautiful as it is, it is also full of tourist traps and imitations of bars/restaurants you see everywhere in big cities. Buenos Aires has more interesting areas.

Good district to live in. Hip, with some good restaurants, night life and very safe to live in. We stayed in 1828 Smart Hotel and loved the area. Metros are nearby and its a great hang-out place for the young.
sweet Bohemian area. Great restaurants and shopping. Easy and comfortable to walk through day or night. It's easy to get to fancier areas or downtown so stay in this cool quieter area.
Bohemian end of town. Markets, pop up shops, artists, designers, great pavement cafes. 5 years ago this area would have been quite edgy, now really up and coming with some great cafes and shops
Great neighborhood in Buenos Aires. great neighborhood to stay in Buenos Aires. Many restaurants and bar and clubs. It is safe to walk by yourself late at night.
Should go. Quaint old neighborhood full os boutiques, cafés, restaurants. Liked the whole area. Some shops have very original stuff from local designers

We walked and walked. It was an extremely hot day and we walked and walked around Palermo Soho. There are tons of shops and restaurants. Few were well air conditioned. It was really too hot to shop. We left and went to the Bullrich mall in Recoleta and were surprised to find the exact same shops. No need to worry about the heat when you are in the mall.

The hippest district of Buenos Aires. Though Palermo Soho is far from being posh, this is the place to be in Buenos Aires. You will not find a cooler vibe, better choice of restaurants, small designer shops, lively bars and clubs, better stocked wine cellars than here.

shop, eat and party. similar to neighborhoods in manhattan......diverse shopping (some native some chains), diverse eats (some native some chains). flea market like stalls around the park and tango night life open way late!!
Worth a vist !!. Beautiful area with loads of restaurants and shops with reasonable prices.Must pay a visit when in then city
Soho style. Visit Palermo Soho while staying in Buenos Aires. It is a trendy district peppered with outdoor cafes and unique shops.
Great neighborhood!. We enjoyed walking, seeing the shops, sampling cafes, and smelling the fragrant linden trees which were in bloom.

Nice area, good for boutique shopping. Palermo in BA, is;SoHo in NYCCastro in SanFranNegenstraatjes in AmsterdamGreat if you like (overpriced) boutique shopping, and nice area for drinks and restaurants. Lot's of hipsters, good for half a day walking around.But be careful, everything here is overpriced; food, clothes.They know how to do some windowdressing in this area.Still I would recommend it.

Shopped on a Sunday. After visiting San Telmo and the Malba we shopped Palermo Soho and had a snack in an upscale burger place. Bought my sons clothes that were very well made and priced. One of the only places in BA that is open for shopping on a Sunday. Fun stores just lots of side walks ripped up but that seems to be all over BA.

Really cool neighborhood. Sadly, I didn't discover Palermo Soho until the end of my trip to BA.It had great shopping, bars, restaurants and cafes. While I enjoyed staying in Recoleta, I think I would have enjoyed staying in Palermo Soho more. Next time!
Don't miss this area. We stayed in this fashionable district and really enjoyed the range of shops and restaurants close at hand. It's walking distance to the Metro. Recommended

I love this neighbourhood. I can stroll here for hours, getting lost down all of the streets, wandering in and out of the artistic kiosks and unique stores. Stopping for coffee at any point is easy and you cant go wrong with any of the restaurants in the neighbourhood. This is always a stop for me in my annual trip to BA.

Eyes to the ground a must!. Watch the dog poo holes and cracks on the sidewalks...do not wear important shoes, high heels for ladies...Area in a bit of disrepair, loaded with areas of smelly garbage. Many nice trendy shops and restaurants. Atmosphere is buzzing...after 9 p.m.

Give me Meat packing district NYC with a Parisian flair. Used to be called "viejo Palermo".. all trendy and chic boutiques, local crafts and great fashion. Bars ,pubs and some very interesting restaurants; all hosted in revival homes with carved façades that are saying grandeur.

A fun and lively shopping experience. There is a fun open market in the square off Honduras. Lots of cafes and fun clothing stores to browse. It is crowded but in a nice sort of way. The surrounding area has great buildings if you are interested in the amazing architecture of Buenos Aires. It has been our favorite spot even though we are staying in the Recoleta, we seem to end up in Palermo Soho every afternoon!

a fun area to stroll. Yes this area is touristy - and we were tourists. So we enjoyed being here. The shops are nice (and a little pricey, but good quality). The restaurants were OK for lunch and coffee. On weekends, craft stalls selling hand made items at fairly low prices are set up on the sidewalk. Our hotel was nearby, and we walked these streets frequently and felt safe and enjoyed ourselves.

Fun, colorful, and full of caracter. It's great to spend a day here, with the beautiful shops and nice and unique cafe's and restaurants. Pay attention to the cool changing pavement and fun graffiti. great to hangout at any time of day or night.
Sunny afternoon. We took the metro to Plaza Italian and walked about 6 blocks into the Soho area. Quirky and fun! Nice cafés and some rather special street art!

Love this area!. If you are in BA, visit and stay in this hip, upscale area. Lots of shopping and great restaurants. Plus I think it's one of the prettiest areas of the city. The streets are also more pedestrian so their is less traffic with a more residential feel.

Sunny afternoon. Great district, easy to get to (take the metro to Plaza Italia and walk about 5 blocks to the north - east. The district is funky, very arty, nice sidewalk cafes and great designer shopping

Nicest area of Buenos Aires!. Amazing place, lots of trees, bars, cafés, beautiful people... Just amazing, mainly on weekends.It's a very cosy, nice place to go either as a couple or for happy hour with friends. Some of the bars have great cocktails for a good price (around ARS 30)

Vila Madelena Wander. Vila Madelena on a Saturday is fun, usually people go there for the night life as it is full of bars and restaurants. But on a Saturday morning it is a humming vibrant place to wander, from the local street market full of stalls selling vegetables, fruits, fish and meet as well as all sort of other eats and "things" makeshift cafes selling Pastels and freshly squeezed cane juice. Wander the streets with a mixture of different boutique type shops. Locals filling up the cafes and restaurants for the Saturday "feijoada" with a beer and generally hanging out. I wish I had remembered my camera as there is lots of colour and amazing graffiti.

Lleven efectivo/bring cash. Muy bueno en lugar, repleto de tiendas, restaurants, cafes y bares, los bares durante el dia son tiendas de ropa y accesorios alternativos tipo bazar, en estos casi nadie acepta tarjetas de créditoVery nice and safe place, plenty of cafe's, restaurants, Shops and bars, at day those bars becomes an alternative market, most of them don't accept Credit Cards, so better to bring cash
beautiful. lovely area for shopping , food , cafes ... more of an upmarket area, can be quite expensive. nice place to spend an afternoon / evening in.

Yuppi. Restaurants, shops and always something going on. Well dressed, charming and tasty but a tad over priced. Nice to visit but for more variety in life keep moving. Easy to get stuck if you are a tourist because of its familiarity, but still some pretty great places.

PROFESSIONALS NEEDED. Palermo Soho is an typical "barrio" in Buenos Aires. At restaurants and bars, service is normally bad, on occasions exceptionally bad. They are in bad need of profesional cooks and servers.My impression is that their staff is not trained in ítems such as customer service, good manners, preparation of the food, the composition of the wine list. Very amateurish and, above all, expensive for what you get in exchange for your bucks or pesos.OK for a saturday midday lunch, but that's about it.
Trendy. This is the trendy part of town that encompasses about 12 square blocks. Very quiet with a lot of upscale stores and cafes.

Pleasant neighbourhood. Very pleasant neighbourhood, spacious sidewalks to walk on, plenty of trees and nice architecture, and a lot of shops, bars and restaurants to go to. Definitely one of my favourite spots to stay in the city.

Good for shopping. Spent a nice afternoon shopping in Palermo Soho. However if you do not shop there may not be much to interest you in this area.msome standout boutiques are Lupe and Carmela Archaval.
Your happy hour is there. Great places to go, have a happy hour and then… have enjoy the BA night life. Lots of pubs, and places to dance until sunrise.

Nice and lively. This is one of the most popular places for having some night fun in Buenos Aires. It´s full of bars and restaurants and on the weekends it´s usually very crowded. If you´re looking to see some of the mnight life in Buenos Aires, this is definetely one of the places to go.

Great shopping area in Buenos Aires.. If you like individual hip boutique shops instead of chains then this is the area to go to shop. There are also lots of restaurants & coffee shops too. A really nice area. Glad I stayed in Palermo Soho.

Beautiful Neighbourhood. Had the luck to stay with a local for a few days in this gorgeous neighbourhood. There are so many lovely parks in this area and lots of shops to peruse if you so wish. There are free bikes provided courtesy of the city to explore the area. Definitely worth a visit if you can't stay here.
Well worth a visit. A very nice area to walk around, have coffee or a meal. Found some lovely small independent shops too including a silver jewellery shop recommended by our guide.
Best neighbourhood. Great to walk around, every street new discoveries. Good restaurants and the best shops. Defenetly the best neighbourhood around Buenos Aires.

More and more stylish every year.. I know Palermo Soho since more than 10 years and this neighborhood is always improving. The area is now more sought after than Recoleta, secund to Puerto Mader. With the crisis of turism foreigners are giving place to locals so you can feel a genuine argentinian genius there.
Go and enjoy!. Cool attractive area, lots of bars and restaurants, excellent gastronomy for all tastes at reasonable prices. You can walk at night without worrying about security.
Another great neighborhood. This is a great area for restaurants and several parks as well as people watching. Walking along Santa Fe avenue is great to get a sense of the real BA.
A great atmosphere. We stayed here in a house that we got through airbnb and we had a great time. Lovely atmosphere in the area with many shops and restaurants

Feels like Outremont in Montreal.... Being from Montreal, the district gave us a local feel, nice shops, cafés, streets, architecture, and we even found a great little spot for lunch that was off the tourist route!

Lovely tree lined streets. so much to do....can spend days walking around. Great boutiques and restaurants. Guatemala, gurruchara, armenia are all perfect to walk around. Not as close to metro but within walking distance.
So much fun!. This area is full of restaurants and bars, the vibe is fantastic and you can stay there until early hours of the morning having so much fun! Definitely worth to visit it.

Good choice of restaurants.. They say you should eat and drink where the locals do, Plaza de Serrano, within the Palermo Soho area, is a good choice. Lots of bars, cafes and restaurants to choose from and all busy, mainly with locals creating a lively and enjoyable atmosphere.

Great area but be prudent..... The Palermo Soho area has a lot to offer....very distinctive, artsy, and interesting shops and restaurants. But I do want to alert people to the fact that late at night, some of the clubs/bars "convert" into activity that is not savory, especially for children. We had arrived very late at our hotel the first night, and were walking on the street after midnight, and we saw some sights which I would have preferred not seeing. During the day and early evening, however, you are perfectly fine here, and I would definitely return because we enjoyed it.
