Great for shopping. Spent a day walking and shopping and people walking...lots of cafes and boutiques....a hip area. Definitely worth a day while in Buenos Aires
Lovely area.. with coffee places, shops, little parks, street fair. the best to walk on Saturdays. Artesanos and small brands but with so much style.
Nice small shops and bars. Nice shops and bars to wander around even a micro brewery and some good Argentinian wine shops its a bit of a walk from the subway but well worth the effort

The place to find boho chic!. Wonderful place to walk around and find great deals in funky clothes! After shopping you can stay and find a good pub for drinks or something to eat in a good restaurant!
Trendy Bar Area. Definitely the best place to eat and drink whilst in the city.Some excellent steak restaurants and the closest thing to a bar culture you will find in B.A. A must visit.

Have a Drink, Dinner and Club Here. Cool location, mostly bohemian and artsy as opposed to the neighboring area, Palermo Hollywood, which is glitz-and-glamour. Have great azado (bbq) at a restaurant in Soho, and catch a concert at a bar as well.
tourism. very touristic place that became famous since some years.a lot of shops, but nothing really very interesting .jumbo supermaret is a good place to buy some salta wines like quara

Happening place. Nice area in BA for night life, good restaurants and general vibe. Lots of stalls selling knick-knacks. However, if you are like me, you have had your fill of flattened bottle cheese boards. Nevertheless, well worth an evening or two.
lovely part of BA. A great area, fantastic restaurants and bars - here's where to head if you want a good meal; We particularly loved Don Julios
Soho. The name Soho already says a lot when you have been to london or to new york! it's a nice fashionable neighborhood!
A great neighborhood. We went to la Paila for dinner. Then we went for a walk in the neighborhood. It's a very hip and modern area. Full of young people and great places for hanging out.
swanky shops, great coffee bars. Bring a lot of dosh if you want to shop here for clothes. Affordable treats, however, are handmade soaps, great coffee bars and gorgeous artisan craft shops
Very good for walks. It is a nice place to walk around. It really feels like you are in the past with all the antiques. Not so fun for kids.

Nice walkable area. We stayed in Palermo Soho and loved it. It was walkable and had a variety of good restaurants and shops. While it was a bit of a hike, we could walk to a Subte station. We had no trouble catching cabs when we needed one. The neighborhood had a nice relaxing atmosphere.

Best Place in BA to stay and visit!. I've always been a big disappointment to Buenos Aires but that changed after I stayed in Palerm Soho. The climate of this district made ​​me change the concepts of Buenos Aires as a WHOLE
A must go.. Very elegant neighborhood with nice shops. You can spend a day walking down the streets and have lunch in a great variety of restaurants and bars.
Excelent place to visit. Don't miss the place, the cafeterias, do not forget to eat some "mezalunas" and appreciate the great neighborhood.

Safe, and Cute Area!. Cute area, with lots of shops and restaurants. Not the best shopping as compared to US, but its worth a look to see local designers (purses) and hand crafts & nick nacks fair (Friday afternoon). I didn't see many clothing shops that were original designers in this area. BA is not strong for its clothing fashion.

Nice area with plenty of restaurants and bars. Lots of bars around the square and many restaurants here. We visited in the winter season so things were a bit quiet but I'm sure its even better in the summer.
Good for shopping.. If you like shopping and cafes during the day and bars and nightclubs at night, Palermo Soho is the place for you. It is a fun place to walk around and window shop.

The cool place to stay in BA. Yep, no question, this area has been redeveloped in a major way, with lots of foreign investment, new boutique hotels and apartments and an influx of top name shops. Osaka, one of my favorite restaurants is here (though they have a new location in Puerto Madero also), and its easy to walk around to go shopping, find a place to eat, or a late night place to party.
Just like shopping in Westbourne Park. Great shopping and restaurants in a lovely neighbourhood. My favourite part of Buenos Aires. Shame there isn't a Metro station close

Fun!. Very different from all other other neighborhoods of BA. Excellent shopping with one of a kind stores, many of which provide local designers; restaurants and bars. We have spent almost every day there!

Fashionable and comfortable neighbourhood. Our BA friends recommended Palermo Soho as a good neighbourhood to make our base in Buenos Aires - they were right. Our apartment was very comfortable and a wide range of facilities were in easy walking distance - subway, supermarket, fruit shop, bakery, delicatessen, and laundry. Not to mention lots of good restaurants and nice shops.

A city within a city. Palermo is a neighborhood in Buenos Aires (Capital Federal) and it is divided in 3 parts (Soho, Viejo and Hollywood) with many restaurants, boutique hotels and nice bars surrounded by nice gardens. You will not want to go downtown once in Palermo!

Trendy fancy neighborhood, that stands to it's reputation. Crowded by night, calmer and delicious to stroll during the day, this neighborhood always makes me feel that I am somewhere farther away than Buenos Aires. Lots of great restaurants, expensive clothes stores and art galleries...

Essential for Shoppers. Not only is Palermo Soho a cute neighborhood, it is a necessary visit for any tourists who like any bit of fashion. There is no lack of style here, and the good thing about traveling from a different hemisphere is that you'll often catch your current season's styles on sale down in BsAs.

PARTY TIME!!!!. If you are looking for party until your body can not party anymore!!! this is the place to look for that!!! there is a million places to go!!! you can pub/bar crawling all night long. Remember that night clubs open from 2 or 3 AM!! till 7 or 8 am so thats when your night change from bar to nightclub! On Godoy street you find some of the bests and remember to look out for your wallet cause sometimes isn't that safe… bring the necessary and don't carry a big purse!!! Enjoy night and have a great dawn!!!
It's where the locals go.... The drinks at Utopia...wow, you get a lot for a low cost. We liked just walking around. Clean area, but there is dog fecal matter on a few blocks so be careful.

Hip and trendy Palermo. In this area you will find chic shops, bars and resto to lower your pace and walk around its fun streets.This is where most of the Buenos Aires Boutique hotels are. Its a happy young fashion old neighbour spirit blend you will experience while living it...enjoy!

Empty during week days!. It was a disappointing visit. Many stores and restaurants are not open during week days and specially during lunch time. There is absolutely no comparison with Soho !
The area has good restaurants and life at night but do not expect anything similar to the amazing New York Soho.

This is where it is at. if it is your first time in BA you'll want to visit and walk around La Recoleta. But, you should graduate to authentic. Palermo Soho is their body and soul of the city; maybe of the country itself

best BA neighborhood for shopping, dining, going out. a bit pricier than other areas of BA, but generally worth it! and any night of the week there's lots to do. I especially like all the new NYC deli-style lunch places opening up

Buenos Aires Trendy Night Life.... Great reastaurants, bars and Disco. Even though some places are kind of expensive, you won't find this top night life, all concentrated in one place like Palermo Soho.
Walk and enjoy. Palermo has been broken into several sub neighborhoods: Soho, Hollywood, Viejo for example. Many cafés and boutiques to enjoy. Plaza Cortázar is a focal point.

Lots of bars, restaurants and trendy shops. Every time we went we kept finding new things. Great fashion shops on Honduras. Excellent little restaurants like Calden del Soho (a little bit away from Plaza Serrano). Plenty of cool bars.

A Den of Thieves. My husband and I travelled to Buenos Aires with every intention of staying in Palermo Soho after reading all the glowing reviews about its great restaurants, nightlife and fantastic sophisticated shopping. After spending the first evening there, we had our reservations. We were dropped off at the main square, which was crowded and blaring techo music from several seedy tourist traps within earshot. There was a market in the middle of the square, which was a pretty poor effort compared to the Recoleta and San Telmo markets. We ate an an OK restaurant that had a tourist oriented menu and browsed the shops before returning to our hotel in Recoleta. Underwhelmed, but determined to give the area a second chance, we returned the next day with a plan to walk the neighborhood, have a lunch in one of the cafes on the square and find a nice boutique hotel. After strolling down and around Honduras, criss-crossing through block after block of run down, dirty buildings with seedy looking bars, and a couple of hip looking restaurants interspersed, we figured we had lost our way, so we asked for some directions. Turns out we were smack dab in the middle of this "hip, urban neighborhood that is just like NY's Soho". Well, I used to live in Soho and guess what? Palermo Soho is its ugly stepchild at best. To top things off, we stopped for lunch on the main square and browsing the overpriced, poor quality clothing shops nearby. We remarked that we felt as if we were being followed. When we sat down for lunch we were immediately accosted by old women and children shoving their wares in your face. My husband pulled out his IPad and immediately there were a flock of vultures bearing down on us. I saw a guy stroll up behind him very close to our table, so I grabbed the IPad and stuck it in my lap. Next thing you know, another guy comes up behind me, grabs my arm and rips my watch off. He ran down the street with my husband in pursuit only to jump on the back of the motorcycle and speed off. Mind you, this was in BROAD DAYLIGHT in the middle of the biggest square in the town. After he escaped, everyone around us just shrugged and went back to what they were doing. I asked about the police and a man in the restaurant laughed and said that they never come around Palermo and this sort of thing happens all the time. We left one very nice watch lighter, but having saved an IPad so I guess we were considered lucky. Bottom line: This area does not live up to the tour guide hype. Tourists are bait and the locals don't care. New York's Soho ought to sue them for sullying the name.

Nice stroll... try to do it in the afternoon or evening. Avoid weekends.. I had a great time walking around this place. There are many restaurants and quite a few stores. Prices are reasonable and the pace is nice. The main square has an interesting "feria artesanal". Check out tripadvisor for advice on restaurants... Some of the restaurants have awful service and pretty mediocre food. I hear that it gets very crowded on weekends. We went on a Thursday afternoon and it was truly pleasant.
Trendy. Well worth a visit. Spend an afternoon exploring. Lots of great cafes and shopping opportunities. In the centre, a square and market.

Great Bars!. Its a very hip place, great for walking...modern design stors and lots of places to choose from for a bite to eat or a refreshing drink. Be careful with robbers and hold your belongings close. Go in the day time! ;)

Trendy, Bohemian part of town. Palermo Soho is a really neat part of Buenos Aires. There are tons of boutiques with super trendy clothing. It's also fun to spend a night on Plaza Serrano, which is located in the heart of Buenos Aires. It's definitely a more touristy part of Buenos Aires (don't expect anything that's authentic Argentine), but it's fun nonetheless. Also, on Thursday evenings there are gallery tours of the art galleries in Buenos Aires. There is a lot of amazing art on display and many of the galleries serve free champagne or beer. It's a great way to spend a Thursday evening!

Palermo SoHo. Palermo SoHo is a fun area to walk, shop, and dine. Some boutiques have very cool window displays and décor. While there are many cafes and restaurants to choose from, my friend visual artist Dolores Palmeiro dined at Guido's which was absolutely amazing!

Great area, close to shops and restaurants!. Convenient and pleasant area to spend your time, after touring and running around all day! Our hotel was in this area, and we feel we made the right choice!
I live there. if you can afford it its the best place to stay in Buenos Aires along with palermo hollywood. Its safe and has good food options...and a looot of nightlife

Trendy and shopping capital of BsAs. This is a very modern and trendy part of BsAs, filled to the brim with funky boutiques and hipster restaurants. Some of the best shopping in BsAs if you like unique and local labels. Strongly recommend a visit if you are a restaurant, cafe, bar, and shopping lover!
Good walk around!. Enjoy this district. Very quaint. Nice restaurants, shops. Great place to relax sip a glass of Malbec. Chill out!

The best neighborhood in BA!. Just spent 12 days in Buenos Aires and i am so happy that we chose to stay in an apartment in Palermo Soho, by Apartments BA. It was ALMOST as to the picture, a little dingier, but pretty close. The neighborhood offers EVERYTHING from shopping to dining to nightlife. Fantastic.
chic neighbourhood. Nice walking area. Trendy. Many, many restaurants. Many small stores. Stores selling clothing. Boutiques.
Good walking and window shopping. Great area to walk around, window shop and then try one of the many restaurants. The wine was cheap and tasty!
Get exposed to old Buenos Aires. Good to go if you are into shopping or just to get exposed to old Buenos Aires city. Cafes, restaurants, parks, or just walking around is a good experience.
great food, drink and shopping. Can't miss, so many options, all good fun. Even people watching is entertaining. we also enjoyed the street fair on the weekend.
Worthwhile. Visiting at night time and sundays during daytime where you will see all the local craftsmanship, very bohemia style

The neighborhood. Lively, trendy, interesting, with many beautiful shops and Cafes. This is the best neighbourhood to stay, in our opinion. It is a mix of local people and tourists and there is a Cafe or a restaurant for every taste!

Hip and Happening!. This is by far the best area to stay in Buenos Aires. Dinner is late and restaurants, cafes and bars are alive and kicking at midnight, even at 2am! Heritage architecture, cobblestoned, tree-lined streets, colourful street art - all mingled with the eateries and designer boutiques - Palermo Soho is just gorgeous!

Stay Here !!. This is the best area of Buenos Aires. Just stay here. Everything is walkable, including restaurants, bars, clubs, shopping etc. Book early and the prices are not too bad either
A lively bar and restaurant scene is at the intersection of Honduras and Serrano. Leather shopping on Gurruchaga. And a lot more that your hotel can tell you about.

trendy and upscale. we stayed at Duque Hotel in Palermo Soho, and we spent a couple of days just wandering the side streets of Palermo Soho. very much enjoyed the vibe of the neighborhoods. numerous trendy shops. fashion and food and young folks made us feel right at home, despite the fact we're no longer young!

Love this neighborhood!. We stayed in Palermo Soho and I am so glad we did! This area has lots of great shopping, restaurants, bars, panaderias, etc. but it is away from the hustle bustle of the more touristy areas. It is very easy to get to those areas by walking (if close enough), bus or by taxi, so we did not feel isolated at all.

Nice place to walk, shop and have lunch,dinner.. It is a nice neighbourhood to walk, make pictures and visit the several shops. There are the brands every one knows but also nice shops with goods from Argentina.

Hip, cool and fun. I liked to walk around there. Lots of stores with bunch of good stuff. You can find very cool things. Is a very vibrant place, with a lot of character. I enjoyed to see the Argentinian clothing and accessories designs. Definitely is a place to go and see and spend the whole day there on a weekend.

Best location in BA. This is a cool and hip area but with lots of charm and character. Restaurants and cafes abound and the shopping (particularly for men) is amazing. Such a relaxed (and safe) vibe, yet close to all attractions, a creative oasis.
Fun and lively. Came on a Sunday. Place was full of people. Cafes, food, drinks. Life went on through at least 11pm. Window shopping is good too. Nice day out

Very good -- as Buenos Aires goes these days. Much better to stay here than downtown. More to do. More within walking distance. Safer. Colorful. Good shopping district. Excellent restaurants. But still a bit down at the heel and ratty. Buenos Aires is nowhere near the city it was 20 or 30 years ago. Graffiti and trash are everywhere, and so are bucketloads of poor people. Do not discount the third world look and feel of this place before you make plans to visit.
Fun afternoon. We enjoyed walking the area and eating lunch outside. It was a good first day activity after a long flight. The stores are interesting, with up and coming designers.

Shops, restaurants, cafes, bars, street art, live music on the street. My B&B (Boho Rooms) was in this neighborhood and I am so glad I stayed there. Lose ourself in the streets, find the main square and take the time to walk around and explore the vintage shops, cafes, and bars.

Soho says it all!. What a great area in which to stay. We spent six days here and loved the family feeling, the restaurants and bars, parks and shops. Just outside of downtown makes such a difference. We walked to the subway and had the city literally at our feet.

Sheek and Safe!. We were fortunate enough to be staying in a hotel near this area. The area is fabulous, some lovely cafes and restaurants where you can chill and watch the world go back. Even during the late hours you feel safe enough to roam the streets. I'm so glad we chose this location whilst on holiday in Buenos Aires.
cafes and shops. Nice area to stroll around and stop at a sidewalk cafe. Lots of local designer shops if you want clothes.

Hip, chic and a ton of fun.... Go here and you get the feeling that this is the part of town that the hippest and coolest live and hang out. The shops are trendy as are the cafe's, bars and restaurants. That said, there are also places that are dives (I love dive type places) that are extremely local and amazingly good. We ate at La Cabrera, a high end steakhouse that was very good, as well as a tiny Mexican dive called Lafabrica del taco. The food was unbelievable...and our waitress/bartender, Sol, made killer margaritas. Thank God we weren't driving after 2 of these! What I'm trying to say is that this neighborhood is cool, chic and expensive, or it is cool, chic and very inexpensive...you can find it all here.

Trendy and vibrant neighborhood.. Having stayed at Alvear Palace for 4 nights prior, we wanted a change of neighborhood. Palermo Soho provided great opportunities to stroll around shopping, dining and great people watching. There were several street markets as well that allowed us to experience life as a local. The produce stands were incredible.

Amazing!!!!. Excellent food, fantastic shopping!!! Fantastic area!!!!!! Truly my favorite area of Buenos Aires! The best shopping in all of Buenos Aires with the best service and the most unique items to purchase
wonderful boutiques and restaurants. Stayed here in the Mine hotel. Lots of cafes, restaurants and shops in tree lined streets. Felt the safest here walking around out of all the suburbs in BA.

Party Central. This is a funky part of town with a big strip of bars and nightclubs. If that's your objective coming to Buenos Aires, then you must stay here. It resembles its New York City namesake or the Plateau area in Montreal.If you're more into sightseeing, stick to Centro. Taxis are a must in this area - it's too far from the Subte.

Love this area!. Great place to spend a day shopping and checking hipster restaurants, Big brands and local culture blend in perfectly and if I would live in Buenos Aires, I would defnitely pick this area to live. Lively but with the feeling of being ouside a big city.

For the young, or young at heart. We were walking back from Recoleta and needed to sit down and have food and drink, so we stopped here. Our hotel had recommended it as a good place to go, as we were staying in Palermo. We could see all the places where there were DJs in the evening, and notices up about deals including beer and empanadas and other things like that. We were too tired to come back in the evening, but if we had been 20 years younger, we definitely would have. Building works in the centre of the square were a bit annoying while we were there, but they are probably finished by now.
Very Argentinian. I did not get to spend much time there but dearly would love to go back. Ate at La Cabrera and it was fabulous.
go for shopping. This is a trendy neighborhood in the city with excellent shops and bars. Nice for strolling around and seeing the elegant porteno people.

Bit tatty but lovely and funky. There were some great markets here most of time we were there. Its a small residential area thats a bit bohemian with some lovely bars and restaurants and interesting shops. Definitely a place to wander around the streets.Just like the rest of BA, the nightlife starts around 10pm and goes on till dawn so expect some noise and good natured rowdy crowds around the main plaza.
Soho Porteno style. Worth a wander, but a bit commercial for my taste. Having said that the side streets have some great street art!
Yeap. So fun. So cool. We went for beer, shopping, wine tasting and tango. You can find many things around the area, special for 40.´s yo to stop and enjoy. What fantastic women around!
nice place every day and every hour of the day. bars, restaurates, shops, every thing u want in the same place. the are nice shops markets in the area

Amazing neighbourhood. Fabulous neighbourhood with hip and gorgeous restos fit for foodies and winos. Lovely designer boutiques. BA's best neighbourhood for sure. It's a must do - I recommend staying there!

Bohemian but not as clean. It's a good area to base oneself if you are looking for shops and cafes within walking distance. Lots to see and check out but maybe with all the construction going on, it's just not as clean with lots of loose pavement tiles. Need to watch where you walk...
Nice area. We enjoyed this chic area. Great little cafes and tree lined streets. Worth a look even if it's just to walk around the streets on a sunny afternoon.

quaint shopping area. For the shoppers there seems to be something for everyone in this new shopping area in town, younger people definitely like it too. Add a little time for traffic getting there on peak hours...
Nice place to visit. Great atmospheric place to enjoy a drink.. Good area, good pubs with serving foods & discos..Friendly staff over there
Nice choice. This area is full of glamour and very good spots to have proper meals, snacks or just a good coffee. Besides you can take nice strolls all around.
Great area. Great vibe, with plenty of eateries for all budgets. We felt very safe here walking at night. Lots of trees, interesting architecture and a local market within walking distance

Street cafes. We hired a private tour of Buenos Aries and our driver recommended that we stop here and enjoy one of the sidewalk cafes and take a leisurely stroll through the area. My wife and I enjoy relaxing at outdoor cafes and this was a worthwhile stop on our private tour of the city
Great Shopping and People Watching. We stayed in this area, enjoyed the local bakery, took a yoga class, had the best gelato, shopped and people watched, great safe area of Buenos Aires.

Charming. Beautiful, trendy, pricey. Darling little places to eat. Very nice.
A lovely place to walk around and have a great meal at one of the many cafes or restaurants.
Great weekend hangout. Checked out the street fairs on Saturday and Sunday. Sunday is the best day. Found some nice things to buy. Fun neighborhood to walk around in.
trendy area. It is the area where the best stores are. Beautiful people like to ride and buy or go to a cafe.Do not miss it.

Not much action during the day, go at night after 10PM. Not much action during the day, go at night after 10PM for the clubs, drinks, a nice dinner or a quick bite. Cabs are plentiful, you will want to take one through the district to find the happening corner, it can change frequently, then get out and join the party.

Used to be the jewel of BA. In 2006, the first winter I lived in Buenos Aires, this was the jewel...there was no soho or hollywood...just Palermo Viejo...lovely small haciendas with classic outdoor cafes and tree lined streets. Sorry folks, you missed it...now it has become so americanized that you may as well be in Soho in NYC. It is now glass and concrete high rises with VENDE signs everywhere. The whole place now looks like one big tourist trap. However, the restaurants on the north side from Fitz Roy to Dorrego are VERY GOOD. Also that area has not been as "Americanized" as the area from Uriarte to Bulnes. Go to El Trapiche on Paraguay for a great parilla or Cafe 22 on Fitz Roy...or if you really want to remember what life in Buenos Airrs used to be like "Las Cabras" on Fitz Roy.

Really nice district. Spend a day wandering around and finding cafes that opened up recently. It's a good experience right next to the outlet district and gives you a little time to kick your feet up. Markets on weekends are a blast.

Neither Palermo, nor SOHO, but.... ... nice area to walk around and compare countless pizza parlors on who's got the cheese made from recycled raincoats and who's got the real thing... some decent graffiti, some nice places, but the name is just like, "call me Jerome" I mean hardly original.

Great markets on the weekends!. For our last 3 nights in BA, we stayed in Palermo Soho. What a lively area, with great restaurants, bars, shops, parks and artisan markets on the weekends.One thing to be aware of is that some restaurants charge a "service fee" which does not go to the staff. It seems to be a bit of a "money grab" and may hurt the amount of tip going to the serving staff. I didn't see this service charge at other restaurants.

Lovely artsy and trendy neighborhood. Lovely neighborhood for walking around and enjoying the nice weather. Lots of art and sidewalk shops and restaurants. Great for people watching and enjoying some tapas and a nice big glass of wine.

Lots to eat and buy!. I stayed at the Palermitano Hotel in Palermo Soho and it is close to many many restaurants. Shops are just a block or two away. I walked to MALBA one day--a long walk for sure but pretty scenery and although it's "real" BA, I felt safe as a woman traveling solo.
Cool neighborhood. Surrounded by fancy boutiques and hip restaurants, I thought I was in San Francisco or Beverly Hills. It's certainly a nice neighborhood to relax under the sunshine
interesting neighborhood. lots of bars, restaurants, shops, little hotels. not especially clean -- frankly, lots of folks walk their dogs on the sidewalks, and don't clean up after them!

Trendy area of city with lots of nightlife.. Lots of stores, restaurants with outdoor seating. There were several small parks with persons selling crafts. The sidewalks are in need of repair and you need to be careful you don't trip.

Lovely. This area is great for strolling around and shopping. There are lots of cafe restaurants and little boutique shops. Tree lined streets and friendly people in this area of BA! There are two sections of El Salvador street on either side of the railroad tracks and you will be able to tell the right one that has the shopping because there isn't very much of anything on the other side. The SoHo side is where you want to be!

yuppies gone too far. Have you ever been to Santa Monica in California? The architecture is beautiful and the tree lined streets relaxing, but the people and the night scene is too precious. If you like polos and pricey drinks you may find yourself at home here.
best place to stay in Bs As. It is a great hood, fantastic restaurants on every street corner, green huge trees in every street and the shopping is fantastic!

Shoppers Heaven. This is where the shopping is at! We walked around BA for a few days not understanding why BA is supposed to have the best shopping in the world...until we found this part of town! Amazing boutique shops and cute restaurants. There is also a hostel in this area if your backpacking this is the place to stay as nightlife is best here!

Chi-Chi funky area. We stayed on Thames & Charcas, 2 blocks form Plaza Italia subway which made access to the Centre of town cheap and easy, as well as walks int he boatanical gardens.  Palermo Soho is crowded with boutiques, which from walking around seems to cater about 75% to women. The area is crowded with restaurants of every type with concentrations around squares/parks like Palermo Viejo. Cafe life is alive and very strong in this area. I think its reasonably safe during the day; though at night the area immediately near the tracks seperating Palermo Soho from Palermo Hollywood, seems a bit more dodgy. The area is also filled with a variety of boutique hotels. so between locals, schools, butchers, bakeries, restaurants,and artisans, its a very interesting area.My biggest dislike in this area was dodging [--] on the side walks.It's horribly disgusting as the porteno's seem to be big dog lovers; but not everyone carries a pooper scooper.The other big downside of the area is the noise at night. Folks go out to eat very late here and as a result traffic and other noise levels are high much later.

nightlife!!!!!. Great place to hang out for an evening--eat, drink, people watch, have some ice cream, coffee, then drink some more, dance, and start all over again. I imagine that if you did that three times in an evening and then watched the sunrise, you would have a sense of the pulse of the Soho. Lots of fun.

stayed a week, memories for a lifetime. Honeymoon stay in an apartment just off Armenia square. Loved the neighborhood. Lot's of great people watching, shops and restaurants. Barely left the neighborhood the entire week.

Know where you are going. I had a great stroll today through Palermo but ask for advice on your walking route before heading out. I had a few - ohboy am I going to get mugged - moments before I found the center of everything.
Nice place to visit if you have more than 1 day in Bs.As.. Plenty of restaurants and shops to visit. It is a good option if you have some spare time after La Boca or Recoleta.

Aptly named!. This was our favourite locale in Bs As and it is easy to say why it is compared to SoHo in New York. If ever we return to Bs As, we would stay in this area. It is a little out of the centre, but has so many cool boutiques, bars and restaurants. Do not miss.
Fun to visit. It's a fun place to people watch, but not really the place for shopping if you are not into the highend stuff.

Fun place to spend the day. BA is one of those cities that 2-3 days are enough. Palermo is a fun place to spend an afternoon. I say afternoon because nothing really opens until at least 1. There are a ton of fun cafes to eat at for lunch with excellent seating outside. Ladies, believe me when I advise HOLDING onto your bag if you sit outside. Do not lay it on a chair, the back of your chair or on the table. There are several shops here to stroll through but we really found the quality of the garments not up to snuff (in our opinion) in nearly every store. Crooked seams abound among other things even in the "high end" shops. If you visit Buenos Aires, you will definitely have to visit this area.

great area if you like to have bars and restaurants all around. This is the area if the boutique hotels, small streets with a lot of bars and restaurants everywhere around. Perfect to stay in if you like late evenings with a lot of people around
Great Location. Wonderful neighborhood. So many great little restaurants and shops. Reminded us of the Village, Soho or Tribeca in New York City.

Great o walk in a worm sunny day. If you are planning on visiting Palermo Soho, think about haing lunch or dinner and plan to buy nice things, is one of the best places to find unique stores, great original designs ans many small restaurants, ideal to go with friends or family and have a great time!
Great for weekend strolling. Great to stroll during the weekend. Get there after 11.30 since porteños party until late, thus open everything late on the weekends.

cute, go on the weekend. lots of cute pop-up street fairs on the weekends there. you can get a good deal but the prices aren't as great as i expected. don't wander too far away from the really touristy areas of palermo because it can get sketchy fast.

Charming, fun and chic. This is a great place to stroll, window shop and eat. The leafy cobble stoned streets, the trendy boutiques and the lovely sidewalk parillas create the perfect setting for a summer evening.

In love with Palemo!. Very different area of all in Buenos Aires, a lots of Cafe's..nice restaurants, shopping places and very nice people around. Love the experience of a dinner with a Live Tango Show, the prices are very affordable for a full dinner. You must go to Palermo. Very cheap the transportation by taxi from the city.

Great area with great restaurants. Palermo Soho and Palermo Soho are great areas to visit in BA. The food and shopping in these area are wonderful. Gay visitors to BA will want to spend lots of time in these two areas!
Fanciest place ever. There's so many designer stores, and on february, they're on sales/discount season, so its so cool to go there
Palermo wandering. This is a very cool area to just wander around the streets checking out the chic shops and having a cafe stop and picking a good eatery as well. Neat area in B.A.!

Foodie's Dream. If you like steak and red wine and leather jackets, look no further. You've found heaven. The best steak meals I have ever had in my life were at restaurants in Palermo. The Malbec wines are also to die for. The exchange rate to the US dollar is very favorable (almost 4:1), so expensive meals were not a big hit to the budget!! Walking here, especially in the springtime, is pleasant and not too warm.Calle Murillo is the street to go get your leather goods, ask any cabbie and they'll take you there. The best stores are in the 500-700 block. If you pay cash they'll give you a discount, usually.Visited Spring 2009

Amazing Neighborhood. We spent our last two nights in Palermo Soho and so glad we did. It is such a vibrant neighborhood...feels like NYC Soho about 10 years back. Great food, shopping, people watching. A must on your visit to Buenos Aires!

A fun area to explore, whether night or day. We wandered through this area during our stay in Palermo Hollywood. The pretty streets are peppered with interesting cafes and bars, making exploration lots of fun.

Good area for restaurants. There are plenty of excellent restaurants in this area. We found it safe to walk around but we did meet a couple of had been violently mugged in broad daylight so be careful and don't wear any expensive jewellry (the woman was wearing an expensive watch). Also I found the streets quite dirty.

Colourful and trendy. Looks like a new in place for young and trendy. Lots of designer shops and nice restaurants. Lots of bars and cafes , lots of market stalls all very interesting . Do not miss going there. Some very good restaurants are to be found there

A very clean area. I love this area of Buenos Aires. This area is clean and very nice to walk around. It is the more "privileged" area of Buenos Aires. It is also the area where I found some of the best small bistros/cafes to eat at. I would recommend just taking a walk in this area to explore the small mom pop areas to visit.

A bit of everything!. A nice and fancy neighbourhood for coffee, drinks (if a bit quiet). The most enjoyable part was the fashion market in all the cafes and bars in the central Square on Saturdays. I found it funky, great price and a great meeting point!
Charming neighborhood. Near Recoleta, an area full of design shops and street markets, cozy restaurants and bistrôs with beautiful,huge parks around. At night,bars and clubs can be found there too.
Is it BA or NY. Gorgeus, tasty & fancy!. If in Buenos Aires don't miss this place full of design stores, restos and friendly people.
Good place to stay. Lots of good restaurants within easy walking distances. Walking all over BA required careful examination of the sidewalks which were in horrible condition excepted in RECOLETA.
Lovely. Pretty place to wander round and pick up soem great Empanadas!Good shops and very safe.Don't belive all that tou read about BA. Tis place is very safe

Fun to walk around. Nice area to walk around. It felt safe. They had a market while we were there that didn't sell that usual tourist goods like tango paintings and nativity sets. Walked out with a very cool purse. Lots of clothing shops that real people can actually afford to shop at. I was tempted, but out of room in my backpack.

Just the right feel. Palermo Soho was calmer, and cooler, than the downtown. It's pace was less hectic, but it had so much to see and do (restaurants and shops). The streets are tree-lined, the shopping is excellent.
Awesome. great area if your the ages of 55-25. outside reasonable cafes that are open pretty late. It's a great area to stay in. This neighborhood is the only place I would stay in, in BA.

The place to stay in BA!. We did some research before going to BA about which neighborhood we should stay, and soon we understood that either San Telmo or Palermo felt more like us. We choose San Telmo for a long stay and then Palermo for just few nights on the way, and back from other places in Argentina. I loved Palermo Soho more I have to say! It's vibrant, full of fashionable shops, nice restaurants, places for breakfast, bars, street markets. San Telmo also has this, but first of all it's much smaller, it's not so alive, it's more touristic (bc it's smaller), and the shops are more antique shops (which I don't like). In my opinion, Palermo Soho is the place to stay :)

A little bit of everything. We were sad that we did not have enough time here.
It had a little bit of everything. We ate and shopped and enjoyed the streets, the people, the food and the crafts..
Loved it!
Must visit!

Disappointing. The neighborhood is quiet and nice to see the local shops, but the economy is clearly slowing down and half the shops are for lease.People are young, but clearly not the best of society (badly dressed, less educated...).Small places to eat and no great options. Except for some trendy good restaurants, this is not a place with great restaurants everywhere you look

Has seen better days. Palermo is one of BA's best area but within that large general area the individual districts vary from grand to rather plain suburban. Palermo Soho has seen better days. Some of the shops are boarded up and the pavements are poorly maintained. You could break and ankle in some of the deeper pot-holes. Despite this appearance it seems safe, both by day and night. Depending on where in SoHo you are it takes about 45 minutes to get downtown if you use the SUBTE.
Gritty Urban Charm. Great little boutiques, tree-lines boulevards, tables on the sidewalk for coffee or drinks -- a great neighborhood.

disappointing. We treked over to Palermo Soho and were disappointed. Where were the interesting old streets? We stopped and had a very good coffee and regouped. We walked to a square with a good artisan market where we bought stuff for the grandchildren. But overall, dont bother.

High End Shopping.... And expensive to boot.Surprized when you can find the same thing at twice the price in a country where most retail is cheap. Mostly for luxury goods.Great high end restaurants and boutique hotels.Try and find the outlet shops, just ask...
SHOPPING!. Loved the vibe, the shops and the people. Can get deals at the right time of the year. Good hours, open till 8pm at night

Beware. Although this is a fab spot for food and fashion, crime is a problem. We were sitting having a early dinner at a busy cafe on a busy intersection. My husband got hit int the side of the head by one assailant whilst another tried to grab my watch or camera. Luckily they got nothing because they did not knock my husband out and he was able to chase them. DO NOT wear any jewelry or watches; don't carry a name brand handbag ; don't carry your passport and only carry small amounts of cash.

getting more upbeat each year. Whilst not yet up to Palermo Hollywood standards it doesnt mean that there arent good clothes and design shops springing up in the area and still the traditional parrillas are reasonably priced.A great icecream shop on the corner of Guatemala and Armenia has great Lemon Pie icecream!

Amazing unique shops and great food. We spent an entire day browsing the cool shops and eating good but inexpensive food. Area felt very safe during the day, but we did not have an opportunity to go at night, but we heard it is safe as well. loved it !

Popular. Palermo Soho is a section of Buenos Aires with many shops and restaurants. It also has a lot of smaller hotels. Garbage collection seems to be a problem everywhere not just in Palermo but I suspect this is a problem that will be resolved soon
Fun. Really fun area to hang out. Sit at a coffee place and just people watch..lot of fun. Lots of art around and go window shopping :)

You have to visit in your stay in buenos arires!. The best restaurants and bars, cofes,and stores are in palermo viejo!
Stay there! If you can not, just visit! Plaza armenia is a nice spot, and there is a street fair on sundays!

Lovely relaxed neighborhood. If you've been disappointed by San Telmo and La Boca (like we have), Palermo Soho might save your day. Nicely renovated colonial style houses and clean sidewalks (-> no dog poo, very unusual in BsAs!) make this neighborhood particular. Nice shops and restaurants. Check out the "Humawaca" store, handbags designed by an architect.

Good shopping district. Lots of shops with various kinds of dresses and items to buy. There are also numerous mobile shops that spring up during the weekends that sell all kinds of goodies from the local vendors. Highly recommend a trip during the weekend.

Amazing neighborhood!. PLENTY of places to eat, drink, shop, see, be seen, party, read, lounge, etc. I traveled all over the city and can say this neighborhood (which I was fortunate enough to be staying in) was hands down the best. A little edgy/gritty (think SoHo or Chelsea in NYC) but you won't want for anything that's not a 10 minute (or less) walk away. I'll stay in this neighborhood on any future visit to BA, no doubt.

Favorite Neighborhood. This was our first visit to Buenos Aires so we weren't sure where to stay, but the Palermo area turned out to be our favorite. Recoleta is ritzy and the hotels are nice, but Palermo has a lot more charm. Lots of restaurants and good, small hotels.

Some Pros and Cons. We rented a lovely apartment in this part of the city for 9 days. Although the area does have some decent cafes and restaurants, the broken up sidewalks are covered with dog poop and pee, trash and garbage. From what we observed, it was not all that unusual for much of Buenos Aires.This is a mostly residential area, which does not have hoards of people like the city center does.There are a number of stylish shops of clothing designers and furniture designers also.The tree lined areas are the nicest. The locals are friendly and helpful.It is located about 3 miles from the city center and there are lots of buses and cabs available.
A nice walking area. A lot of very interesting shops and people watching area. Pleasant place but lots of shope close in middle of the day

The "hip/trendy" neighborhood. We stayed at a hotel in Palermo during our 4 days in BA. This area is billed as hip and trendy, the "place to be" of BA. While the restaurants and shops are certainly fitting, I was a little taken aback by the overall look and feel of the area. I am sure a lot of it is based on the recent economic downturn. There were sections of missing/broken sidewalk that puddled into mud. And look down when you walk! Dog walkers here are not fond of cleaning up after their pets. Still, we always felt safe, even leaving the discos as late as 4am. It really is the place to be in BA, especially at night.
Loved this area!. Beautiful buzzing area with cobbled streets, markets, designer shops, quaint coffee shops and restaurants and then a happening night life after hours! highly recommended!

Fun part of the city. Great shops, great night life, this is a fun part of the city that should not be missed. It can be a little noisy but it gives the visitor an idea of the hipper side of this old city.
Hot spots. Many new restaurants. Quite a few looked as though they had recently opened but there were other that must have been there for decades.

Favourite part of the city, by FAR. I've been in Buenos Aires 8 times now, and I ALWAYS return to Palermo Soho... Small cozy boutique hotels, the best and most modern restaurants in town, European style architecture, loads of bars, shops, restaurants etc etc. Stay here, you won't regret it!
lots of fun. just go and wander around. lots of interesting, creative stores with Argentinian merchandise. definitely worth an afternoon.

Fashionable area. Palermo Soho is a small area of Palermo Viejo around Plaza Serrano. It is a newly fashionable area for design, fashion, bars, restaurants and street culture. The traditional low houses have been adapted into boutiques and bars, creating a bohemian feel. It’s a pleasant place just to stroll, people-watch and window shop.

Great place with an awful name. They should hang the person who decided it was a good idea to rename Palermo Viejo as Palermo Soho and Palermo Hollywood. It makes me sick to my stomach to realise that we South Americans still need that stupid sort of validation. Name aside, Palermo S*** is charming, vibrant and unmissable.

Great Area in BA. Great up and coming neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Lots of boutique hotels to stay in and restaurants to eat at. Lots of patios to eat / drink beer at. During the day we walked around the streets of Palmero Soho and visited small boutique fashion stores. Busy night life – dinner starts around 10:30 followed by bars and or clubs.
Bars and restaurants galore. I loved this neighborhood. Lots of places to eat and drink and all sorts of funky design and fashion shops.

The one and only place to stay. This is all you are looking for: nice parks during the day and great night life at night!
Palermo Soho is a trendy neighborhood where you can find anything you want, ranging from tango to clubs to late dining places. Recommended for long stays in Buenos Aires as well.
Great Walk!. Very nice place to spend an afternoon browsing shops, cafes and people watch. It reminded us of Soho in New York.

Artsy. This neighborhood is teeming with shops and restaurants.
Great location to walk around and a great jump off point
to other parts of the city

Beautiful Fashion Boutique Area. A short ride or moderate walk from central Buenos Aires, the Palermo Soho area was one of my favorite spots. There are several quaint cafes, taverns, and international fashion boutiques that are a pleasure to visit for walking and shopping. It has a young urban professional and artisan character that is unmatched anywhere else in the city during my visit.
lovely neighborhood. Fun place to walk around, little cafes, a really nice neighborhood, colourful, busy enough without being too crowded, my fav in Buenos Aires!

Palermo Soho. great neighborhood. lots of hip restaurants and chic boutiques. But as a budget traveler really couldn't afford stuff in the boutiques even though still quality goods and is cheaper than the States. Take the subte to plaza italia and the gist of the neighborhood was couple blocks in the opposite direction from the big parks in Palermo. I stumbled upon a street market and was able to purchase some great items.
Excellent place for outing. Plenty of bars and restaurants, VERY SAFE at night, even good for lodging if you don t mind being a little bit out of center town. Taxis are cheap in B A.

Love Palermo Soho--great design stores!. It's a bit like NYC Soho in the 80s before the chain stores moved in. And much more peaceful, with parks and cobblestone streets. It's really great. The design stores are very inventive, architecture is great. Many restaurants as well.
Hippie style. Very cool atmosphere highly recommend specialy sunday afternoon.Alternative designers shopsVery nice restos

Shady oasis in a big city. This lovely area in Buenos Aires has cobblestone streets lined with, huge trees and lots of good restaurants, bars and shops. It can be quiet if you pick the right street and hotel. Our first hotel was four blocks from the zoo and parks and we recommend that area. Our second hotel was farther north on the edge of Palermo Soho and the surrounding streets were iffy. It is very walkable and we felt safe, although we took all appropriate precautions. Very trendy and known for its great food.

A trendy area of BA. This is a nice neighbourhood to check out with lots of cafés and restaurants to relax in. Quite a few shops as well and near some nice parks to check out, although possibly not worth hanging out in.

Great neighborhood to stay. Palermo Soho is definitely a great neighborhood to stay in BA. Lots of restaurants and shops are at your doorstep, and the access to the subway (Subte) and busses are great. Close to a large park and tons of vibrant nightlife. I've heard Palermo Soho is among the safer neighborhoods, but there is a lot of crime in BA, especially pursesnatchings and muggings. We felt fine walking around Palermo but we were advised to be cautious all the same and I would definitely recommend that. Don't have your cameras out visibly and keep belongings close to you. I still recommend this barrio highly, but it is not immune to the crime factor plaguing BA

Loved it! Best shopping in BA for young unusual style. I was feeling a little let down by the famous Recoleta shopping (a bit boring and traditional) so I decided to head over to Palermo Soho. Thank goodness I did! Its a great area - huge number of small cool and unusual boutiques mixed in with trendy cafes that wouldn't be out of place in Barcelona or indeed NYC Soho. I ended up getting leggings hand printed with images inspired by movies (!), some very beautiful soap shaped like rose petals, and a silk tunic from the designer Garza Lobos. Lunch at Felicidad was great, too. Tip: go to plaza serrano and then go East and North - almost all the stores are in that area (it would be easy to miss)
Nice Neighborhood. We really liked the areas of Palermo and felt that it was very enjoyable in terms of shopping and eateries. There are many options and it's a good place to walk around.

This has to be one of the coolest suburbs in the world.. This is a really exciting suburb. Beautiful cobbled streets. Great shopping and fantastic restaurants. Unbelievable shop designs. A must see. Also make sure you eat at Mott.
Great neighborhood. Very walkable yet cozy and trendy. Lots of restaurants and shops, very comfortable to walk around and find nice things to do.
Interesting area and some nice restaurants. Nice to walk around and have a meal. Seems to be an area that is in the middle of changing foe the better. We enjoyed it
overrated overcrowded. I found the area just blah. And the crowds to be horrible. The stores are overpriced and not very fashionable. The restaurants are LA wanna be's.

Plaza Cerrano. Palermo Soho is the best place to stop if you need to have everything close ... the city's best restaurants are located in Palermo Soho and everything seems to start and branch out from Plaza Serrano ...

Just like NYC soho.. If you have some extra time in Buenos Aires, pass by Palermo Soho. If you have ever been to Soho in NYC, it is just like it. Actually streets are wider. Eat ice cream at Persicco!!

Lovely area to walk around!. Lots of great shops and restaurants. Plaza Viejo (off Malabia and Nicaragua) is a cute park with surrounds shops and restaurants, and a great (but small) market on the weekends from 10:30am-7pm (roughly). There's one stall with great leather handmade goods sold by the artisan, including lovely passport holders. Another man sells handmade leather notebooks at very reasonable prices. I found this market to be very reasonably priced overall. Also a great place to bring a book and read or people watch!

It could so be anywhere. My opinion is bias -- I live overseas to meet the locals, not spend all my time with the expats. So if you didn't know you were in BsAs, it is understandable. That said, if you want food and drink that is 'just like home' this is the area to head for.

Excellent place to spend a few hours. This neighborhood is a great place to eat, drink, shop, and walk around. Usually when places compare themselves to NY, I find them disappointing. But not with the Palermo neighborhood in BA. Cobble stone streets, a great vibe, and an outdoor crafts festival (at least on weekends). And did I mention the shopping? Bring your wallet!

A little bit of everything BA. This is a great place to walk around - especially on a Sunday when it seems that all of Buenos Aires comes here to do the same. That walk can include browsing many high end shops or can include browsing many stalls on the street, selling items made from local artisans. Or forget walking and sit down in one of the many cafes, restaurants or bars. For free entertainment sit in Plaza Armenia. We people watched while listening to a group of drummers. This all made for a very pleasant afternoon.

Another view of BsAs life. Especially in the winter, the neighborhood doesn't particularly look inviting. Dodging dog poop everywhere also makes it less than enjoyable to stroll through the streets and check out the restaurants and shops (why doesn't anyone seem to care in any of the residential areas of the city?!) Yet there is clearly lots of potential for a good time in this area and it gets very lively when the weather warms up. If you find it too trendy here, just head on over to the other side of the tracks to Palermo Hollywood where there is a fair share of good restaurants as well.If you've had your fill of Recoleta and the main tourist areas, it is worth a visit to get another slice of Porteno life. Super-easy to get to with buses and Subte D from downtown area.
Nice area. I lived nearby and whilst it might be a little decayed in areas, enjoyed the facilities

Good times!. I really enjoyed visiting Palermo Soho! It is a nice and trendy neighbourhood of Buenos Aires, where I found the nicest shops and restaurants! A highlight of my afternoon was the "Feria" in Plaza Serano with a lot of artesanal products and the Tea Time in Boutique Hotel Nuss, were I had a lovely Cafe con Leche with some delicious home-made Pastry! Highly Recommendable!

Great shopping and attractions. We stayed at a small boutique hotel and loved Palermo Soho. The location was very central to a lot of our planned activities, we were able to do a lot of shopping, and we were able to go for a few drinks in Plaza Serrano :) Close to the "Plaza Italia" subway station, which is also another plus, as we spent a lot of time on the green subway line while in BA.

We rent an apartment in Palermo Soho annually. and have done so for 7-8 years. It is our favorite BA area because of ambience, walkability(is that a word?), dining, and shopping. We have rented in dffferent parts and this past May we stayed about block and half from Plaza Serrano. I have always gone there on the weekends as one can pick up some very nice items at reasonable prices. This time I bought a well made leather messenger bag for under $50 US.Also only on weekends on streets off Plaza Serrano, there will be something which I call flash shops selling clothing, shoes, accessories by local designers. You can get some good deals but need to be careful in examining for quality .These places can get very crowded and chaotic but that is part of the experience. I love to just stroll around and pop in and out of shops. Mama Racha is a great place to have breakfast or lunch on the patio and people watch. Mark's is good for coffee and one can do WiFi there as long as you like if not a busy time.

Find Plaza Serrano and begin.... ...Palermo Soho and Old Palermo melt into one another, so in my case it was always hard to know when I was actually IN the 'soho' (replace with 'coolest') area of this cool neighborhood. One method that works rather well is to forget the term and head for Plaza Serrano, which is a straight shot down Jorge Luis Borges street from Plaza Italia. Once there you can know you are in the center of the Soho area. Take in the many cool bars, cafes, nightclubs, and parrillas and absorb the ethereal ambience of 'Soho-ness'. Proceed in any direction, examine the boutique-like shops, make sure to sit down for something. If you keep walking, eventually the surrounding feeling will wear off into a subdued normality and you will know that you have left Soho behind. I have often found that turning around it has disappeared altogether.
Energetic place. Excellent to have a walk, go to the street market or taste a good meal on a peacefull part of the city.
Nice neighbourhood. just relax, enjoy some outside shopping in a trendy spot!

Wander here for a few hours, options for lunch. This is an easy to navigate section of Palermo, with lots of interesting stores, murals, green spaces, and options for lunch or dinner -- especially in the area immediately around Plaza Cortazar.

Great place to walk from 2-8pm (wed-sun). Great neighborhood to walk around and browse the cute stores. The really happening days are Wednesday to Sunday from about 2-8pm. Monday & tuesday they are open, just less busy - and that's all part of the fun of this neighborhood.
Leather Paradise. Well worth getting up to a large collection of leather factory shops, quite literally having the factory "out back", situated on Murillo/Malabia, at the top end of Scalabrini Ortiz.

Perfect Holiday Suburb. We spent 12 days in an apartment in Guatemala just off Thames. It was central, vibey and an easy enjoyable walk to Plaza Serrano and all the happening nightspots, restaurants and boutiques in the area. Santa Fe and the Plaza Italiana (from where a bus or the subway could easily be accessed) were a 5 minute walk away. There was a tenedor libre in Thames near Santa Fe where an eat as much as you want grill meal was 40 pesos. A litre of beer about 20 pesos.
Great for shopping. This is a very nice neighborhood with a lot of shops and boutiques if the best kind
Nice neighbourhood. To go and visit neighbourhood. I enjoyed entering in creative shops and antiques, having mate in one of those pop caffes and spending some time at Plaza Serrano
Good neighborhood. for shopping, go for a coffe, a drink, eat and meet young alternative people. My favorite place in the whole Capital Federal.

Nice but be vigilant. It seems fun to walk around all the boutique stores and sidewalk cafes and listening to the street artists playing South American music. There are also police walking around. Do not let your guard down! A guy came up to us pointing some dropped money by our chairs. While we were wondering to see did we dorp our bills, he stole our bagpack and we did not even notice it for a while.

A cool place with all kinds of stores. This is a fun place to hang out almost any day. You could find a different store every day you visit here. Get yourself to plaza serrano, have a beer or coffee and people watch. There is a repetition of certain stores (shoes, and women's cloths) but there is something for almost everyone in this neighborhood. Well, except history buffs and lovers of dog poo free evenly paved sidewalks.
Great Area for shopping. You have it all here. Sunday street fairs, great designer boutique shopping and a big area of outlet shopping. Also great restaurants and parks.

The place to be in BA. A must visit....you can get lost in the streets and always come across something so cool. Loved the stores for fashion and the coffee shops with amazing dulce de leche for breakfast.
Great neighborhood for a stroll.. There are many good restaurants, bars, pastry shops, and stores in Palermo Soho. The intersection of Sorrano and Honduras is particularly good.

One of my favourite places in Baires. Chock full of beautiful architecture, pretty boutiques in amazing buildings, vibrant cafes, all kinds of trendy restaurants and crowds of people by day and night. Everything shuts late so come at any time. The two main squares in Palermo Soho have great ambiance. You can easily spend a whole afternoon and night wandering the streets.

Excellent place to visit day and night. There are actually 3 parts to Palermo - Palermo, Palermo Soho and Palermo Hollywood. Palermo Soho is really worth a visit: great choice of bars, restaurants and shops. We felt safe at all times during the day and night. It's a great place just to go and explore and try different food and drink at the many bars.

Not the Real BA but superb shopping at people watching. 10 years ago this was a run down and uninteresting area. Now its full of shops and bars. some good some not. Lovely place to enjoy a whole afternoon. Plaza Armenia is a good square. Avoid Plaza Serrano.

An amazing place to visit. Actually, to me Palermo is the coolest area I've ever being in. Bring with you your running shoes (there is a big park with lakes to go running), bring your dancing shoes (lots of clubs and Tango places to go dancing), bring your coolest shoes (hey, they call this area "Palermo Soho"!).It's full of shops, bars, clubs, green areas, music, happy people around... com'on, I loved it.Ah, be careful with thieves (camera and bags). I've never met one there... bad I know that there are.

Beautiful neighbourhood. I really like Palermo, it is a really nice place for a walk, to sit in a cafe and to hang out. This specific part of palermo is really charming because you can see lots of new designers and their creations everywhere.

I LOVE this place!. Such a cool vibing place! Expensive shopping but wonderful! great contemporary culture feel. Fantastic dining and cafes! really good on a Saturday or Sunday because all the markets open up on the streets.It is a really pretty place that feels different as soon as you walking into the area. A definite place to eat out at night with friends and do some shopping (or just looking).

Good shopping, good cafes, good restaurants. Our favorite neighborhood in Buenos Aires. Good clothes that you won't find anywhere else. Liked the clothes at Erre Raquel Gallardo, and Rapsodia. Nice restaurants and cafes.
